title: 2012 Lamborghini Gallardo
subTitle: Just what you need to get your blood pumping
metaTitle: 2012 Lamborghini Gallardo Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2012 Lamborghini Gallardo Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Lamborghini Gallardo is a study in relativism. The less expensive of the two Lambos on the market, it comes around $200,000, roughly the price of a starter home in a nice neighborhood. Slower and far subtler than the Lamborghini Aventador, it still tops out just above 200 mph and has unmistakable supercar looks. In a machine like this, everything comes second to power. The Gallardo doesn’t disappoint, offering a choice of a 550-, 560-, or 570-horsepower engine. The 570-horse version takes the Gallardo from 0 to 62 mph in less than four seconds and 0 to 124 mph in about 10 seconds. Some models are available with all-wheel drive to help keep control of the car at high speeds. The Gallardo seats two, and is available as a convertible with a soft top. Compared to its stunning performance, the interior is rarely the selling point on a Lamborghini, but that doesn’t mean it falls short. With leather seats, available two-tone or monotone, available accents like a suede steering wheel, and an available navigation system (albeit, a very expensive one), you will be plenty comfortable while zooming past plebs in their sedans.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competition:
1. Audi R8 GT
2. Ferrari 458 Italia
3. McLaren MP4-12C

Cool Tech:
1. Extreme speed, hugely powerful engines.
2. Available Navigation system with satellite radio.
3. Available all-wheel drive.

Looks:
1. Eyecatching Lamborghini design.
2. Leather interior available in two-tone.
3. Available as soft top convertible.

title: 2013 Suzuki SX4
subTitle: The SX4 is small, fun for all, and visually appealing, but could get much better mileage.
metaTitle: 2013 Suzuki SX4 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Suzuki SX4 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Suzuki’s only compact car within American borders, the SX4 is a fun car for the young and the young-at-heart alike. It doesn’t matter if you’re a committed sedan-driver or prefer a car with five doors: the SX4 has something for you. The Crossover is the only SX4 that comes with all-wheel drive; if you go with one of the other models, you’ll have to settle for front-wheel drive. The car’s 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine will get you up to 29 miles city and 33 miles highway on a single tank of gas. However, given the size of this car as compared to some of its competitors, the mileage should be better. The upside is that many features that come in expensive comfort and convenience packages on other cars come standard on the SX4. On most trim levels, you’ll find your SX4 equipped with illuminated steering wheel controls, a leather-wrapped steering wheel with cruise control buttons and audio controls, and a remote keyless entry system.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Ford Fiesta
2. Honda Fit
3. Nissan Versa
4. Scion xD

Cool Tech Items:
1. Illuminated steering wheel controls.
2. Air filtering system.

Looks:
1. Kabuki-inspired headlamps.
2. Wheel arch protection molding.
3. Body-colored mirrors and door handles.

New for 2013:
1. New seat fabrics.

title: 2012 Lotus Evora
subTitle: If you want a Lotus this is the one
metaTitle: 2012 Lotus Evora Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2012 Lotus Evora Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Evora is the only Lotus currently sold in the United States, which makes it the only option for Lotus lovers looking for a new car. The Evora lives up to its racecar pedigree with good starting and stopping power. The interior is sparse but not unattractive, with available contrast stitching and front racing seats. Options include a touchscreen navigation system, a backup camera, and iPod and MP3 connectivity. The area behind the front row can be configured to hold two seats, but the Evora still wouldn’t quite count as a four-seater, earning a 2+2 designation instead. Don’t let that deter you if you’ve got a young family, though. The available back seat comes equipped to handle child seats. If you’re not enticed by a tight squeeze in the back seat, that area can turn into a low bench instead, perfect for hauling shopping bags (though maybe not groceries for five). It gets good gas mileage for a sports car, making almost 30 mpg on the highway, but even the base model is more expensive than most competitors. That said, you won’t be bored behind the wheel of the Evora.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Audi TT RS
2. BMW M3
3. Porsche Cayman

Cool Tech:
1. Available touch screen navigation system.
2. Available iPod and MP3 connectivity.
3. Available backup camera.

Looks:
1. Slightly offbeat but distinctive exterior.
2. Standard front racing seats.
3. Available rear seat.

title: 2013 Suzuki Kizashi
subTitle: The darling of the Suzuki line gives you the chance to own a fun, mid-size sedan without the mid-size price.
metaTitle: 2013 Suzuki Kizashi Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Suzuki Kizashi here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Although known for their compact cars, Suzuki engineered the Kizashi to be its flagship car for the 2010 model year. Since then, the Kizashi hasn’t undergone many changes and, like its siblings the Grand Vitara and the Equator, exists under the average buyer’s radar despite sales promotions that can reduce the price of the car by $3,000. With a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine, the Kizashi has a fuel economy of up to 23 mpg city and 30 mpg highway, making it great for those with long, cross-town commutes. Since long rides can be less than stimulating for the driver, Suzuki offers a Rockford ten-speaker sound system and heated leather seats on the Kizashi Sport SLS, which also allows you to stream music from your iPod via Bluetooth if the AM/FM radio doesn’t hold your interest. Long drives to and from work can also be hard on your car, but they shouldn’t be a problem with the Kizashi; this car held up after driving at top speeds on the Autobahn and rolling over cobblestone roads in England. You’ll be able to hear your music or news over the outside road noise thanks to the Kizashi’s sound installation even at high speeds. The French seams on both the cloth and leather seats add a nice touch to the car’s roomy interior.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Fusion
2. Hyundai Sonata
3. Toyota Camry
4. Volkswagen Jetta

Cool Tech Items:
1. SmartPass keyless push start system.
2. Rear sonar and backup camera.

Looks:
1. Crimson Red Metallic exterior paint.
2. Eighteen-inch wheels and spoiler on Sport models.

New for 2013:
1. New navigation system.

title: 2013 Maserati GranTurismo
subTitle: A beautiful speedster for four
metaTitle: 2013 Maserati GranTurismo Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Maserati GranTurismo Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Maserati GranTurismo may be less expensive than a Ferrari or Lamborghini, but that doesn’t mean it’s low class. Clocking in above $100,000, the GranTurismo makes a statement and it makes a fast one. With a top speed of about 177 miles per hour (or 285 kph, if you ask the Italians ) this sporty four-passenger won’t leave you breathing someone else’s exhaust.  The GranTurismo manages 20 mpg on the highway – nothing to brag about but not a deal breaker either, especially compared to similarly mediocre performance from its competitors. The GranTurismo is available as a coupe or a soft top convertible. The interior is luxuriously appointed in leather – available in ten colors ranging from beige to bright red or deep blue – with chrome accents and a standard Bose Surround Sound audio system. The GranTurismo’s V-8 engine was engineered by Ferrari, so it should be plenty loud and fast enough to keep drivers happy. Though it’s a little too chubby to really compete with the best of the best, the GranTurismo is an excellent vehicle for someone looking to add a little comfort to their sports car experience, and it certainly won’t blend in with the crowd.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Aston Martin V8 vantage
2. Bentley Continental GT
3. Jaguar XKR-S

Cool Tech:
1. Ferrari engineered V-8 engine.
2. Standard Bose Surround Sound system.
3. Several selectable drive modes to adapt to driver preferences and driving conditions.

Looks:
1. Dozens of exterior and interior color choices.
2. Good-looking design.
3. Plush interior.

New for 2013:
1. New Sport model replaces S and S Automatic models.

title: 2013 Suzuki Grand Vitara
subTitle: For on- or off-roading adventures, the Grand Vitara is your go-to car
metaTitle: 2013 Suzuki Grand Vitara Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Suzuki Grand Vitara here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: If your definition of fun involves off-roading and adventure, but Jeeps aren’t really your cup of tea, Suzuki’s Grand Vitara may be of interest to you. The Grand Vitara is a great blend of on-road comfort and off-road capability, making it a car that you can use for work or play. If you’re concerned about the wear and tear this car can take, don’t worry too much. You should always take car of your vehicle, but know that the Grand Vitara does have a reinforced inner-framework similar to ones found in pricier trucks and SUVs. Most of the car’s trim levels come standard with automatic transmission, but a five-speed manual transmission is also available. The Grand Vitara doesn’t come in a wide array of colors unlike its competitor over at Honda, but it does come with a variety of features that come standard on the base model. Not only do you get the expected power windows, keyless entry, digital clock, and air conditioning, the base model comes standard with touchscreen navigation; if you upgrade to the Premium or Limited level, you’ll have access to hands-free calling and nüLink! Services, which gives you access to two- and three-dimensional maps, speed limits, movie listings, and parking locations so you never have to fumble with printed maps and papers again!
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Jeep Liberty
2. Honda CR-V
3. Mitsubishi Outlander
4. Toyota RAV4

Cool Tech Items:
1. Google Local Search.
2. Micron air-filtration system.

Looks:
1. Sixteen-inch steel or alloy wheels; eighteen-inch aluminum-alloy wheels.
2. Satin nickel accented interior trim.

New for 2013:
1. New front fascia and grille design.
2. New turn signals and exterior colors.

title: 2012 Maserati Quattroporte
subTitle: Four doors, five seats, and a Ferrari engine – what’s not to like?
metaTitle: 2012 Maserati Quattroporte Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2012 Maserati Quattroporte Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Maserati Quattroporte is a beautiful melding of the fine engineering and speed of a Maserati with the practicality of a sedan with room for your luggage. This five-seater is propelled by a Ferrari-engineered V-8 engine that allows it to reach speeds of almost 170 miles per hour. The Quattroporte handles curvy roads like a much smaller car, but the cabin still feels roomy and luxurious. The leather seats can come in one of ten colors, and with a similarly wide selection of exterior colors and Maserati’s extensive personalization options, the Quattroporte can be exactly the sedan you’ve always dreamed of. It goes without saying that this doesn’t all come for free. The Quattroporte lives in the $130,000 range, and with its unimpressive gas mileage (12 mpg in the city, 19 on the highway) the Quattroporte would be expensive as an everyday car. However, the fuel economy tradeoff is one you’ll make with any performance automobile, and while it would be easy to double your fuel economy by driving a Honda, the accompanying decline in driving enjoyment would be far more painful than a costly trip to the pump.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Aston Martin Rapide
2. Jaguar XJ
3. Mercedes-Benz CLS-class

Cool Tech:
1. Standard navigation system with iPod connect.
2. Ferrari engineered V-8 engine.
3. S model can go 177 mph.

Looks:
1. Available pull-down tables for rear seats.
2. Available power sunroof.
3. Sleek, sexy exterior design.

title: 2013 McLaren MP4-12C
subTitle: The gentleman’s supercar
metaTitle: 2013 McLaren MP4-12C Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 McLaren MP4-12C Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: McLaren’s latest supercar is just what the doctor ordered. The two-seater packs performance under the hood, with a 592-horsepower V-8 engine that tops out above 200 miles per hour. The rear-mounted engine is visible through the rear windshield, and the engine noise emitted from the rear of the car is the stuff of a car nerd's dreams. The McLaren’s presence is not quite as striking as a Ferrari’s or Lamborghini’s, with its less aggressive front end and more refined rear. It does feature jackknife doors for a bit of fun, and benefits from sleek, futuristic carbon fiber accents throughout. McLaren will offer a new hardtop convertible Spider model for 2013. The Spider’s top can raise and lower at the touch of a button even while the car is moving. The interior is perfectly suited to the car, with carbon fiber accents, a minimalist center console, and well-designed racing seats with color-contrasting accents. The MP4-12C is the elder statesman to Ferrari’s boisterous man-child, but that doesn’t mean it won’t knock your socks off.
Fun-O-meter: 10

Competition:
1. Ferrari 458 Italia
2. Lamborghini Gallardo
3. Porsche 911 GT2 RS

Cool Tech:
1. 592-horsepower V-8 engine.
2. Top speed over 200 mph.
3. Air brake deploys under heavy braking.

Looks:
1. Carbon fiber elements throughout.
2. Available as a hardtop convertible.
3. Attractive interior.

New for 2013:
1. New Spider hard-top convertible model.

title: 2013 Suzuki Equator
subTitle: The Equator is here for all your Suzuki-brand towing and stowing needs.
metaTitle: 2013 Suzuki Equator Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Suzuki Equator here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Motorcycles and boats are great, but they aren’t always practical. If you drive a Suzuki motorcycle or have a Suzuki outboard motor on your boat, you can transport them using a Suzuki-brand truck. The super-practical 2013 Equator has a towing capacity of up to 6,300 pounds, meaning that you should have little or no trouble pulling your boat out of storage and putting it in the water just before fishing season begins. In addition to this, both the Extended and Crew Cab body styles have flip-up rear seats, fold-down passenger seats, and storage boxes for moving smaller things that either can’t or shouldn’t be hitched to the back of a truck. Suzuki believes in providing its customers with options, so in addition to your choice of cab body styles, you also have the choice of a long or short bed for your Equator, as well as a five-speed manual or automatic transmission. However, keep in mind, stick-shift aficionados, that the manual is only available with the 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine. The automatic only comes with the V-6. For your driving convenience, this pickup truck also features heated leather seats and a sunroof for those sunny but bitter cold winter days.
Fun-O-Meter: 3

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Colorado
2. GMC Canyon
3. Honda Ridgeline
4. Nissan Frontier

Cool Tech Items:
1. Dual power mirrors.
2. Front reading lamp.

Looks:
1. Chrome rear bumper and front grille.
2. UV cut glass and privacy glass.

New for 2013:
1. Three new exterior colors.
2. Larger headrests.
3. Electronic stability control available on all models.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz C-Class
subTitle: Whether it’s sedan or coupe, the C-Class combines refinement, luxury, and performance.
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz C-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Know Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz C-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: No matter what variant you choose, the Mercedes-Benz C-Class is well-built, luxurious, comfortable, and quiet. Who wouldn’t want a car with those attributes? Maybe it’s not quite as racy as the BMW 3-series, but some people are seeking refuge and technology. The C-Class certainly has plenty of the latter. The standard “mbrace” suite of telematics features now provides Internet access, and you can use mbrace2 and your smartphone to keep the valet from joyriding during your hot-stone massage. (This is called “geofencing.”) The C-Class comes as a sedan or coupe, and there are engines of four, six, and eight cylinders. The 3.5-liter V-6 with direct injection and automatic start/stop, which is available in the all-wheel-drive C300 sedan, is a great choice. On the other hand, the rockin’ C63 AMG has a 6.2-liter V-8 that puts out 451 horsepower and takes no prisoners. A seven-speed automatic is included with every C-Class model. Sport sedans--notice that we’re pushing sport--have a flat-bottomed steering wheel and heartbreakingly beautiful ash wood trim. You’ll kick yourself for getting the floormats dirty. Optional driver assist keeps track of surrounding traffic and can guide the car back into its lane. Were you checking your Facebook page?
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Infiniti G
2. BMW 3-series
3. Audi A4

Cool Tech:
1. Latest mbrace does everything but let the dog out.
2. For backseat passengers, available iPad docking behind front-seat headrests allows full use of tablet computer.
3. In-vehicle hotspot, a $500 option, adds a router that supports up to four wireless devices.

Looks
1. Available in three shades of silver.
2. Illuminated door sills are an option that will always add a note of welcome.
3. AMG Sports Package Plus features special sport interior with contrasting seatbelts.

New for 2013
1. The mbrace2 technology is upgraded with Internet access and remote interaction.
2. The 3.5-liter V-6 adds direct injection for extra wallop and efficiency.
3. Driver assistance can guide the car back into your lane.

title: 2013 Subaru XV Crosstrek
subTitle: The all-new XV Crosstrek from Subaru let’s you have plenty of room for all of your adventures with a rugged action look, while still being comfortable to drive.
metaTitle: 2013 Subaru XV Crosstrek Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Subaru XV Crosstrek here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The XV Crosstrek is a new vehicle from Subaru for the growing compact crossover utility segment. Basically, the engineers at Subaru started with a five-door Impreza, raised it three inches off the ground for better ground clearance and made it more rugged looking. The XV Crosstrek has rugged capability and Subaru’s all-wheel drive system to tackle any recreational sport or task, while not losing any of those interior comforts you have grown to want. The XV Crosstrek offers rear seat legroom close to that of a mid-size vehicle. If you want to feel good about saving the environment while driving, this is the car for you. The XV Crosstrek is built in a zero landfill plant and is a partial zero emissions vehicle. You’ll also feel good getting close to 33 MPG with the larger gas tank. The XV Crosstrek comes with two transmission choices: a five-speed manual transmission and an automatic with manual control mode and steering wheel-mounted paddle shifters. The XV Crosstrek will keep you and your occupants safe, coming standard with Subaru’s advanced frontal airbag system. This system is equipped with airbags that can sense how close you are to the airbag. The XV Crosstrek is proof you can have a rugged vehicle without having to surrender comfort and gas mileage.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Mini Countryman
2. Nissan Juke
3. Hyundai Tucson

Cool Tech Items:
1. Hands-free calling.
2. Subaru'a advanced frontal airbag system.
3. Eco Gauge: your personal fuel economy gauge.

Looks:
1. 8.7 inches of ground clearance (three inches higher than the Subaru Impreza).
2. Grocery bag hooks in the cargo area.
3. Removable, waterproof cargo tray.

New for 2013:
1. All-new vehicle for 2013.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CL Class
subTitle: Offering style and speed while exceeding the technological capability of some developing countries.
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CL Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CL Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: This large and stylish coupe offers remarkable performance, including surprisingly good handling characteristics. With the base turbocharged 4.6-liter V-8 making 429 horsepower, the CL550 will perform as well as a sports car on a challenging road. A larger and even more powerful V-8 in the CL63 AMG is the favorite among four engines offered, although buyers might disagree and choose either of the two turbocharged V-12 powerplants. The larger, 6.0-liter one affords you the opportunity to play with 621 horsepower. Five- or seven-speed automatic transmissions are offered. If you’re planning on snowy winters, you should keep in mind that the CL550 is the only all-wheel-drive model. The exterior design is highlighted by pillarless construction that leaves an undefiled sweep of side glass. Body colors are subdued and dignified. Besides being exquisitely beautiful inside, the car is loaded with amenities. Heated and ventilated front seats offer a massaging capability, for example. Every conceivable active safety system is available, helping the driver to stay awake, see their blind spots, distinguish pedestrians at night, and keep the car in its lane. Some developing countries yearn for this kind of power and technological capability.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Aston Martin DB9
2. Bentley Continental GT
3. Maserati GranTurismo

Cool Tech:
1. Attention Assist “reads” steering input and other factors to create a driver profile, then steps in with audible warnings when appropriate.
2. Spotlight Function uses infrared beams to detect roadside pedestrians and then flash light from the headlamps on them.
3. Splitview dual-content display screen allows the driver to see navigation information while the front passenger watches a movie, listening to the sound through a wireless headset.

Looks
1. Pillarless hardtop design sleekens the profile.
2. Top-stitched leather and hand-polished wood are found throughout the interior.
3. The aggressive stance is accentuated by available nineteen- and twenty-inch wheels.

New for 2013
1. Grand Edition Package adds three custom exterior and interior colors.
2. Twenty-inch wheels available with Grand Edition package.
3. AMG styling also available with Grand Edition package.

title: 2012 Subaru Tribeca
subTitle: Subaru’s not-so-little-engine-that-could doesn’t look like it can and may be on its last leg…or wheel
metaTitle: 2012 Subaru Tribeca Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Subaru Tribeca here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: For all the redesigns that Subaru has made to its other vehicles, it seems that the Tribeca has been left behind to stand on its merits during the time it has left as a viable member of the Subaru lineup. Based on the Outback, the only changes that have been made in the Tribeca’s seven-year history are a new head-restraint design and a new addition to the paint palette. It’s unfortunate, because the Tribeca is a pretty well-appointed car. As with all Subarus, it comes standard with all-wheel drive and has a passenger volume similar to its more popular sibling. Like the Outback, it’s also good for hauling any sort of equipment that you find yourself transporting; the Tribeca has a cargo area under the rear floors in addition to flat folding second- and third-row seats. The up-to-date audio system and a rear-seat entertainment system will keep both you and your little passengers entertained. Heated front seats come standard for your driving comfort and an auxiliary air conditioning system to keep all your backseat passengers cool on hot, sunny days. The car’s only shortcomings are a tight third-row and a fuel economy that doesn’t compare to that of its competitors.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Traverse
2. Dodge Durango
3. Honda Pilot
4. Mazda CX-9

Cool Tech Items:
1. Rear vision camera.
2. Reverse assist sensors.

Looks:
1. Eighteen-inch alloy wheels.
2. Tinted glass on rear sides and liftgate.
3. Ambient illumination in footwells and on doors.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class
subTitle: Less roomy and more expensive than the E-Class, but you can’t take your eyes off it.
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Often imitated, never quite equaled, the CLS has managed to stay ahead of its followers in the swoopy four-door class by offering a nice selection of powertrains and pouring on the technology. To the full complement of active safety and driver-assistance aids, the CLS-Class now has the latest mbrace software as standard. Internet access is a part of that package, including Mercedes-specific apps, and mbrace2 more or less makes your smartphone a remote control device. That starts with locking or unlocking the doors from a distance but extends to “geofencing,” which ensures that your car stays within a prescribed area and under a predetermined maximum speed. Touché, joyriders! But joyriding may be in order because there are three engine choices, starting with the CLS550’s 4.6-liter turbocharged V-8 that produces 402 horsepower. Mercedes-Benz’s 4Matic all-wheel drive system is available. The CLS63 AMG comes with a 5.5-liter turbocharged V-8 producing 518 horsepower. Automatic stop/start, a fuel economy feature, shuts off the engine when the car sits at a stoplight, then refires it when the driver lets off the brake. Not enough output for you? The optional performance package wrings 550 horsepower out of the same engine.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Audi A7
2. BMW 6-series Gran Coupe
3. Jaguar XJ

Cool Tech:
1. Standard lane keeping detects a drifting car and brakes the appropriate wheel to guide you back.
2. Active LED headlights “look” around curves and vary the range of high-beams.
3. Automatic stop/start technology is included with CLS63 AMG.

Looks
1. Nineteen-inch wheels are available.
2. Two matte-finish exterior colors are available.
3. Leather upholstery is available in nine colors.

New for 2013
1. The mbrace2 technology is upgraded to include Internet access.
2. Mbrace2 adds “Control” functionality with geographic restrictions on the car’s travel.
3. Over-the-air diagnostic capabilities are added through mbrace2.

title: 2013 Subaru Outback
subTitle: Subaru offers a safer way to transport everything-and the kitchen sink-in the 2013 Outback.
metaTitle: 2013 Subaru Outback  Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Subaru Outback here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It handles like a car, but it is truly an SUV. Subaru’s 2013 Outback, the world’s original crossover vehicle, offers its passengers all of the capabilities of an SUV with the stability of a sedan, making it an excellent car for both short trips to school or the market and longer family road trips. Featuring an estimated fuel economy of up to 30 mpg highway and a super-quiet ride, you’re not very likely to find a better deal for $24,000-$32,000 amongst the Outback’s competitors.  If you’re the outdoorsy or sporty type, you’ll be particularly taken with the 71.3 cubic feet of cargo space and the adjustable rear roof crossbar, which will allow you to cart a variety of bulky sporting gear with you on your adventures or at least ensure that you have enough room to transport the majority, if not all, of your daughter’s belongings to college without having to leave her behind! The Outback also makes certain that all your trips to campus are safe ones thanks to Subaru’s new EyeSight system, which will activate the breaks before a collision and a stereo camera that will let you see the obstacles in your path before you feel them.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Escape
2. GMC Terrain
3. Jeep Liberty
4. Toyota Highlander

Cool Tech Items:
1. EyeSight driver assist system.
2. Harman/Kardon audio system (on the Premium model).

Looks:
1. Ground clearance of 8.7 inches.
2. Redesigned grille, headlights, and bumper cover.

New for 2013:
1. New engine with more power.
2. Bluetooth steering wheel control switches.

title: 2013 Subaru Legacy
subTitle: A neglected star in the mid-size firmament, the Legacy stands head and shoulders above the competition.
metaTitle: 2013 Subaru Legacy  Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Subaru Legacy here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: So you’re looking for a dependable car and you think you’ve seen all that the automakers have to offer by spending hours watching sunlight bounce of one windshield after another? Well, don’t make a decision just yet. The Subaru Legacy has been a solid performer since it’s redesign in 2010 and will continue to be with its new changes for 2013. Under the hood of the 2.5i, you’ll find the brand-new, 2.5 liter Boxer engine which achieves up to 32 mpg highway with standard all-wheel drive, making the Legacy the most fuel-efficient sedan on the American market. One of the great things about mid-size sedans is that they accommodate both the short and the tall comfortably, but the Legacy is roomier than most, boasting 103 cubic feet in passenger volume. However, more car can sometimes mean reduced visibility. That is remedied with the new EyeSight driver-assist. Not only does this system provide you with lane departure warnings and identify obstacles in traffic, but EyeSight can activate the brakes to avoid collision. So before you decide to put a hard-earned down payment on a Fusion or a Camry, take some time to look at the safer, sportier 2013 Legacy.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Ford Fusion
2. Toyota Camry
3. Honda Accord
4. Volkswagen Passat

Cool Tech Items:
1. EyeSight driver assist system.
2. Bluetooth hands-free phone capability.
3. Hill holder system.

Looks:
1. Redesigned front for a sportier look.
2. Body-color side mirrors.

New for 2013:
1. Brake override system.
2. EyeSight driver assist system.
3. Second-generation Lineatronic continuously variable transmission.

title: 2012 Subaru Impreza
subTitle: The Impreza is the best bargain for fuel economy and comfort, while still being a fun car to drive.
metaTitle: 2012 Subaru Impreza Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Subaru Impreza here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The new Impreza is the roomiest Impreza ever with a longer wheelbase. Your passengers sitting in the back won’t complain anymore of little to no legroom, as the Impreza offers two more inches of legroom than previous models. You will also be more comfortable in the driver’s seat, gaining a little more room for hips and shoulders. There are also numerous compartments to stow your life’s necessities, like phones and purses. With more room comes more fuel economy in the Impreza. This isn’t normally something you would see in the same sentence, but Subaru has figured out how to get more than 30 percent more fuel economy in the Impreza. Even equipped with Subaru’s well-known all-wheel drive, the Impreza is projected to get 27 MPG city and 36 MPG on the highway. The new Impreza’s exterior has gone through a makeover, returning to Subaru’s original sporty design. You can choose between a four-door or five-door model, both with bolder and more dynamic exterior designs. Both models come standard with carpeted floor mats, a standard item most automakers don’t offer. Also offered is more flexible storage space, including a split-folding back seat, perfect for transporting life’s adventures. For the money, the Impreza combines practicality with bold, sporty design for a reasonable price.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1.Chevrolet Cruze
2. Ford Focus
3. Honda Civic
4. Mazda 3

Cool Tech Items:
1. Voice-activated GPS.
2. All-wheel drive.
3. Audio streaming connectivity with any device.

Looks:
1. Power moonroof.
2. Roof rails.
3. Four- or five-door models.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz E-Class
subTitle: If you can’t find the right shape or features and then have fun with it, your meds aren’t working
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz E-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz E-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: There’s always the secure feeling that comes from being in a well-built car. Which car, exactly? Try the E-Class coupe, convertible, sedan, or station wagon. Here’s the thing about the E-Class: it’s the anchor of the whole Mercedes-Benz brand. They sell it in every body style except one that can fly off and rescue mountaineers. It wouldn’t have surprised us if James Cameron found an E-Class when he took his Deepsea Challenger to the bottom of the Pacific. An interesting thing has happened with the E-Class since the ninth generation model appeared in 2010. It got sportier and more rewarding to drive. Now, as few as four or as many as seven people can climb inside. In addition to the E350’s punchy 3.5-liter V-6, the order sheet includes a strong and efficient turbo-diesel V-6 and a cyclonic pair of turbocharged V-8s. New to the lineup is the E400 Hybrid, which combines the gasoline-fed V-6 making 302 horsepower with an electric motor that allows for some electric-only maneuvering and assists the gas engine once under way. Also new as standard features in the coupe and convertible are heated front seats and the latest-generation mbrace telematics software. A seven-speed automatic transmission serves in all E-Class forms.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Audi A6
2. BMW 5-series
3. Infiniti M

Cool Tech:
1. Convertible includes Aircap deflector that automatically rises from the windshield header to diminish turbulence.
2. Convertible’s optional Airscarf is neck-level heating vents integrated into the front seats.
3. Automatic stop/start, a fuel economy feature, shuts off the engine when the car sits at a stoplight, then refires it when the driver lets off the brake.

Looks:
1. E550 coupe and convertible roll on eighteen-inch five-twin-spoke AMG wheels.
2. Larger, eighteen-inch five-spoke wheels come with the E350 coupe and convertible.
3. Sport sedans have three-bar grille while luxury sedans have four bars.

New for 2013
1. Coupe and convertible have electromechanical steering for 2013 and all-wheel drive is available in the coupe.
2. Heated front seats are standard in the coupe and convertible.
3. E63 AMG sedan now comes with Premium 2 package standard.

title: 2013 Subaru BRZ
subTitle: When you get into the all-new BRZ, all you’ll want to do is drive.
metaTitle: 2013 Subaru BRZ Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Subaru BRZ here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The all-new Subaru BRZ is a big departure from its siblings, equipped with rear-wheel drive, not the all-wheel drive Subarus are known for. But don’t let that scare you from a machine that was built to enhance what we do best: drive. First, you can keep your keys in your pocket while driving the BRZ Limited with its keyless access and start. Once you put yourself in the driver’s seat and feel the standard leather-wrapped steering wheel, all you have to do is push the start/stop button and you are ready to embrace your inner racer. The BRZ comes with a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission, but if you want to experience the BRZ as it was intended, go with the manual. Driving the BRZ should be fun, and the engineers at Subaru want to make sure you keep your hands on the wheel and enjoy driving. The BRZ comes standard with a GPS touchscreen that is voice activated so you can concentrate on driving when you need to find your way. The driver also has easy-to-use controls to allow the driver to focus on the task at hand, driving.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Honda Civic Si Coupe
2. Hyundai Genesis Coupe
3. Scion FRS
4. Mazda Miata

Cool Tech Items:
1. Voice-activated GPS.
2. Push-button start.
3. Dual-zone climate control.

Looks:
1. Standard leather-wrapped steering wheel.
2. Standard HID headlights to see distant objects.
3. All-new Subaru engineered vehicle specific platform.

New for 2013:
1. New vehicle for 2013.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz G-Class
subTitle: The over-endowed SUV is further endowed with new safety and tech features, and the AMG version returns
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz G-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz G-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: A problem with the G-Class is the way its invincibility is compromised by old-fashioned elements like hard-to-use door handles and slow-acting steering. Yes, it’s awesomely capable, but it has a cramped backseat. People buy it anyway, and not because of the off-road obstacles it will conquer. Who would take their $113,000 truck out on the Rubicon Trail? Rather, the G-Class has a cool, authentic look that comes from form following function, and makes the driver feel like the hero in an apocalyptic action-adventure film. For 2013, Mercedes-Benz has refreshed the G with new interior appointments. Foremost among them is a freestanding, seven-inch, tablet-style central display unit. There are also steering-wheel-mounted paddle shifters for manual control of the seven-speed automatic transmission. A suite of technological systems is added for parking and blind spot assistance, with adaptive cruise control thrown in for good measure. Outside on the G’s square nose, LED daytime running lights are now in place. The 5.5-liter V-8 in the G550 now produces 388 horsepower. Displacing the same volume, the G63 AMG’s turbocharged V-8 makes 544 horsepower and is equipped with automatic stop/start for fuel economy purposes. Special trim and twenty-inch wheels distinguish the AMG.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Land Rover Range Rover
2. Infinity QX56
3. Lexus LX570

Cool Tech:
1. A two-speed transfer case and three electronically lockable differentials give the G-Class superior off-road ability.
2. The AMG model’s automatic stop/start, a fuel economy feature, shuts off the engine when the car sits at a stoplight, then refires it when the driver releases the brake.
3. Mbrace2 adds telematics functionality for external control of systems via smartphone.

Looks
1. LED daytime running lamps and LED tail lights are now included.
2. Side-mirror caps have LED turn indicators.
3. The AMG’s twenty-inch wheels are available in black.

New for 2013
1. A sleek, freestanding seven-inch flat screen serves as the central display.
2. Parking assistance and adaptive cruise control are added.
3. The G63 AMG’s sophisticated turbocharged V-8 makes 544 horsepower.

title: 2013 Smart ForTwo
subTitle: A small car for big cities
metaTitle: 2013 Smart ForTwo Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Smart ForTwo here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Smart is still a curiosity in the American market, despite the increasing manufacture of ultracompact and electric cars. The Smart ForTwo is great for what it was designed for – short trips in big cities where parking and gas are too expensive to warrant a full-sized vehicle. It does a fantastic job of parking in tight spaces, and can park with its nose to the curb where a normal car would have to parallel park. The gas mileage is good – 34 mpg in the city, 38 mpg on the highway – but not a huge jump over some fuel-efficient or hybrid sedans. The Smart makes up for this by being much cheaper than most hybrids, starting just above $13,000. The very small package assumes certain sacrifices, and the long-legged among us might feel claustrophobic in the Smart’s tiny interior. Luckily, a convertible model is available for those who like to feel the breeze in their hair or need extra headroom. Smart made the wise choice of keeping the interior sparse and not cluttering the already tight space. With a top speed under 70 mph, the Smart won’t get your blood pumping, but it is a good option for city dwellers, and fits well with an environment-friendly lifestyle.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. Fiat 500
2. Mitsubishi i
3. Scion iQ

Cool Tech:
1. Best fuel rating of any gas automobile.
2. Convertible top can raise while moving.
3. Made of 85 percent recyclable material.

Looks:
1. Interchangeable body panels for constant color changing.
2. Clean interior with bright trim.
3. Many color choices.

New for 2013:
1. New electric model expected to extend range.
2. Electric motor increases top speed in that model.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK-CLass
subTitle: The smallest Mercedes SUV calls time out for a thorough makeover and returns much improved.
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK-CLass Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK-CLass Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Standing tall and looking boxy, the GLK-Class is notably different from its chief competitors at Audi and BMW. While being somewhat roomier and offering better outward visibility, it hadn’t been as much fun to drive. Did Mercedes stand around and pout over it? No, they sought to improve the GLK for 2013. The exterior is refreshed with LED daytime running lights, a new grille, and bolder-looking bumpers. New LED taillights brighten the rear. Inside, the driver looks at a colorful instrument display and everyone can enjoy the optional, multi-color ambient lighting. The latest “mbrace” telematics system connects vehicle and smartphone. Of course the GLK offers a host of features for driver assistance and active safety. The biggest news, though, is that the GLK350 is fitted with a 3.5-liter V-6 that benefits from the addition of direct injection and makes 302 horsepower. It includes automatic stop/start, a fuel economy feature, which shuts off the engine when the car sits at a stoplight, then refires it when the driver releases the brake. Rear-wheel drive is available, or you get all-wheel drive with the GLK350 4Matic. The turbo-diesel-powered GLK250 Bluetec joins the lineup early in 2013. So now there’s something for everybody.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW X3
2. Audi Q5
3. Infiniti EX35

Cool Tech:
1. For rear passengers, an iPad dock is included.
2. Active curve illumination lets headlamps sense an oncoming turn and swivel, directing the beam into the corner.
3. The coming 2.1-liter turbo-diesel engine far outdoes the larger gas V-6 in torque output, a key measure of engine performance in city traffic and highway passing maneuvers.

Looks
1. AMG styling package adds unique wheels, lower-body panels, and aluminum roof rails.
2. Panorama roof is option.
3. Twenty-inch wheels are optional.

New for 2013
1. Refreshed exterior styling with new headlamps, bumpers, and grille for a bolder look.
2. The 3.5-liter V-6 benefits from the addition of direct injection, making 302 horsepower.
3. Brushed aluminum accents and more expansive wood trim highlight the interior.

title: 2012 Scion xD
subTitle: Smaller, cheaper, and more efficient than the xB
metaTitle: 2012 Scion xD Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Scion xD here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The xD was Scion’s replacement for the xA, but it looks more like a shrunken version of the utilitarian xB. The xD is about a foot smaller than the xB, and it is not quite as tall or as wide as its sibling.  It also sits on a smaller wheelbase. Despite it’s small size and low weight, the xD doesn’t exactly shoot off the starting blocks. However, the nimbler of Scion’s five-door offerings gets the best fuel mileage of the fleet (excluding outlier Scion iQ) at 33 miles per gallon on the highway.  The xD’s interior isn’t quite spacious, but neither is it cramped. The rear seats fold flat to allow for increased cargo space. Like all Scions, the xD’s list of add-ons is almost overwhelming, and goes far beyond usual offerings of upgraded wheels and window tints. With available accessories like shocks, mufflers, and brakes, and a base price at $16,000, the xD is perfect for an enthusiast on a budget. Don’t wait too long, though. There is talk of replacing the xD with an all new model as part of Scion’s never ending crusade for novelty.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Chevrolet Sonic
2. Honda Fit
3. Kia Soul

Cool Tech:
1. Standard Pioneer audio system.
2. Many available mechanical accessories.
3. Available factory navigation system.

Looks:
1. Sport seats for driver and passenger.
2. Underfloor storage in cargo area.
3.Orange backlighting on instrument panel.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz M-Class
subTitle: With so many SUVs in the lineup, the ML has the odd effect of pointing back toward the E-Class station wagon
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz M-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz M-Class Buyer's Guide. With so many SUVs in the lineup, the ML has the odd effect of pointing back toward the E-Class station wagon.

pageElements.text: The ML-Class SUVs are tall and heavy, so their handling on the road is mediocre. The ML350 BlueTec 4Matic’s turbo-diesel lags before delivering its low-end power and then wheezes when pushed hard. The exterior design is cluttered and derivative, as though mighty Mercedes has been looking over its shoulder at the Koreans. Inside, there’s only seating for five. The optional On- and Off-Road Package offers a two-speed transfer case, locking center differential for crawling ability, and six transmission settings, all of which will significantly reduce the difficulty of your trek to drop off kids at the junior high school. (Maybe this redundant capability explains why a simple rear-wheel-drive version of the ML350 is now offered.) Mercedes piles on the standard features with the latest “mbrace” telematics system to link with your smartphone, an anti-collision system, and a colorful new instrument panel. In case you don’t want to wait until you reach the resort to get a massage, the optional contoured seats will give you one. (If it’s a hot-stone treatment, though, see your dealer.) Yes, there are turbocharged V-8 versions of the ML. But what we want to know is, if you seek a Mercedes with utility, why not look at the E-Class station wagon instead?
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Acura MDX
2. Jeep Grand Cherokee
3. BMW X5

Cool Tech:
1. Anti-collision system is new for 2013.
2. Two-stage transfer case with differential lock and six transmission settings is available.
3. A rear-seat iPad docking station is available.

Looks
1. Upholstered dashboard is now standard in the ML550 4Matic.
2. Multicolor ambient lighting and illuminated front door sills are available.
3. Twenty-one-inch wheels are available with the ML63 AMG.

New for 2013
1. Rear-wheel-drive ML350 joins the lineup.
2. Sculpted front seats with massage feature are optional.
3. Latest mbrace telematics system.

title: 2012 Scion xB
subTitle: The box that made Scion, reimagined.
metaTitle: 2012 Scion xB Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Scion xB here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2012 Scion xB is not the unapologetic box that made us love Scion. After its first redesign, the car looks significantly different, and hasn’t improved much on handling or fuel economy. Some of the xB’s issues are mitigated by an available package from Toyota Racing Development that smooths out the handling, and the xB is extremely utilitarian for such a small car. It seats five with the seats up and boasts enough space for a move across town or a trip to Home Depot with the seats down. The spacious interior echoes the xB’s oddball aesthetic with a center-mounted dashboard and color-contrasting audio control nobs. That unconventional arrangement fits with the xB’s unique attitude, and if the base interior feels sparse it can be conveniently upgraded with all manner of Scion extras. Some of the most enticing add-ons include a navigation system and a rear-seat DVD player. Scion’s “one and done” business model could mean that the 2012 xB will be the last one, though the demise of the lovable toaster-on-wheels has yet to be confirmed. Even if it is on its last leg, the xB is affordable, practical, and it makes a statement as soon as it turns the corner.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Chevrolet Sonic
2. Kia Soul
3. Nissan Cube

Cool Tech:
1. Available rear DVD player.
2. Abailable Toyota Racing Development package.
3. Orange ambient lighting behind dashboard.

Looks:
1. Undeniably distinctive.
2. Spacious interior and back seat.
3. Standard first aid kit.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz S-Class
subTitle: Fast and sleek or efficient and sleek, the S-Class encompasses nearly everything you could want in a car
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz S-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Carfs
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz S-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The S-Class is at the end of its product cycle, which means an all-new model will be coming later in 2013. It also means the present car has become as refined as royalty. Balanced and precise, offering a supple ride, it’s a delight to drive. The turbocharged V-12 S65 AMG that produces 621 horsepower will go from 0 to 60 mph in 4.2 seconds, so it’s fast, too. Or for efficiency’s sake, you can select the turbo-diesel V-6 in the S350 Bluetec 4Matic or the S450 hybrid, which returns 19 mpg city and 25 mpg highway. Overall, there are six engines in the lineup, and all but one is turbocharged. These range from gas and diesel V-6s to a pair of V-8s and also a pair of V-12s. Seven-speed automatic transmissions have to cope with all this output except for the particularly beleaguered five-speed in the S65 AMG. All-wheel drive is only offered in combination with the diesel. Of course, the interior of the S-Class is lavish enough for a pasha or a panjandrum, should you need to transport one. And there is no stinting on the active safety and driver assist features, including Parktronic, which will dazzle your entire embassy staff when it pulls itself against the curb.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. BMW 7-series
2. Audi A8
3. Lexus LS

Cool Tech:
1. Three-stage cooling system withholds coolant until engine warms for quicker heating of cabin.
2. Seven-speed automatic transmission uses a low-viscosity fluid for less friction and better fuel economy.
3. Splitview dual-content display screen allows the driver to see navigation information while the front passenger watches a movie and listens through wireless headphones.

Looks
1. Nineteen- or twenty-inch wheels are optional with all non-AMG models.
2. Panorama roof that’s standard on the S600 is available on other non-AMG models.
3. Sport body styling is available on the diesel, hybrid, and V-8 models.

New for 2013
1. Premium 2 package with parking assistance and massaging seats is standard on S350 BlueTec 4Matic, S400 Hybrid, and S550.

title: 2013 Scion tC
subTitle: A two-door Scion for the street racers among us
metaTitle: 2013 Scion tC Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Scion tC here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Scion tC is smaller and faster than most of Scion’s other boxy offerings. With one of Scion’s most powerful engines, two doors, five seats, and a hatchback, the tC is the slightly more practical choice for people who can’t commit to the enviable FR-S. This is not to suggest that the tC is in any way boring. It is quick to accelerate and comes in a limited-run RS model (available only in “Absolutely Red’) that features a racy body kit and some Toyota Racing Development enhancements.  A six-speed transmission adds fuel efficiency, helping the tC inch its way above 30 miles to the gallon on the highway. The tC’s fabric seats are less than attractive, but the rest of the interior is pleasing, and the power moonroof is a nice touch. New for this model are standard Bluetooth and a Pioneer audio system. As with all Scions, the base package is just the beginning, with available after-market upgrades ranging from high performance air filters to illuminated doorsills. With a base price just under $20,000, the tC is one of Scion’s most expensive models. But with strong performance and a touch more sophistication than the brand’s other youth-mobiles, it is still a good choice.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Honda CR-Z
2. Hyundai Veloster
3. Kia Forte Koup

Cool Tech:
1. Six-speed transmission increases fuel efficiency.
2. Standard Pioneer audio system.
3. Available navigation system and XM Satellite Radio.

Looks:
1. Aggressive exterior design.
2. RS comes with body kit.
3. Many aftermarket accessories available.

New for 2013:
1. Standard Bluetooth connectivity.
2. 2013 Release Series 8.0, only 2,000 distributed.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class
subTitle: Lighter in weight, bursting with power, and trimmed to a fare-thee-well, the SL is all-new for 2013
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: In creating a new-generation SL-Class, Mercedes engineers devoted an inordinate amount of effort to making the car lighter. The aluminum body weighs 275 pounds less yet provides better crash protection and is stiffer than the previous steel body, which results in superior ride and handling characteristics. That’s like finding a pair of lightweight shoes that are comfortable and good-looking. The SL is a hardtop coupe and open-top roadster with a power top that folds away in twenty seconds, but when it’s up, the optional Magic Sky Control lets occupants control the darkness of the glass panel’s tint. For top-down comfort, vents in the seats deliver heat around your neck during the fall color tour. As beautiful as the SL is on the outside, it’s every bit as alluring and voluptuous inside. The seats are heated and actively ventilated (optional) for comfort. Nearly every driver assist and active safety feature you could think of except incoming missile avoidance is included. Under the long, creased hood is the SL550’s turbocharged 4.6-liter V-8 making 429 horsepower; this is outfitted with automatic stop/start for fuel economy purposes. Pusillanimous V-8 and V-12 units are in the two AMG models. A seven-speed automatic harnesses the output of all three engines.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Aston Martin V8 Vantage
2. Jaguar XK
3. Maserati GranTurismo

Cool Tech:
1. Two FM radio antennas are embedded in the windshield, while two other antennas receive signals for AM band, GPS, phone, and mbrace2 telematics system.
2. Windshield wiper fluid only sprays on downstroke when the top is lowered.
3. SL63 AMG has Racestart launch control feature for maximum efficiency on takeoff.

Looks
1. Nineteen- and twenty-inch wheels are optional.
2. Sport steering wheel with perforated grips is optional.
3. Perforated rear brake discs, showing your degree of seriousness, are optional.

New for 2013
1. Hands-free access to the trunk is achieved by kicking through a field at the rear bumper.
2. Mbrace2 telematics system adds Internet and remote access capabilities.
3. SL65 AMG with 612-horsepower V-12 engine now uses seven-speed automatic transmission.

title: 2012 Scion iQ
subTitle: Smarter than a Smart Car
metaTitle: 2012 Scion iQ Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Scion iQ here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: At first glance, it’s easy to mistake the Scion iQ for the Smart ForTwo. Both are tiny city cars with high gas mileage and relatively few practical uses outside the urban center. The iQ has improved upon some of Smart’s drawbacks, however, and has the dubious honor of being the smallest four-passenger car for sale in the United States. The iQ is often marketed as a 3+1 car instead of a four-seater, because the front driver’s seat is positioned further back than the passenger seat, eating up much of the rear legroom on that side. The Scion earns essentially the same gas mileage as the Smart, with 36 mpg in the city and 37 on the highway, but where it really shows its advantage is in the ride. Despite its short wheelbase, the iQ doesn’t jostle you over every bump in the road. It is also extremely maneuverable, with a turning radius almost three feet shorter than the Smart’s. If you’re looking for an ultracompact car with a little more legroom, the Fiat 500 is a safer bet, but the iQ has the rest of the bases covered.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competition:
1. Smart ForTwo
2. Fiat 500
3. Mini Cooper

Cool Tech:
1. Standard Bluetooth and HD radio.
2. Available touchscreen audio system with iPhone connectivity.
3. Rear seats fold flat for more cargo space.

Looks:
1. Available in bright colors.
2. Spartan center console avoids cluttering small space.
3. Contrast stitching on steering wheel and shifter.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class
subTitle: The small coupe-roadster has many virtues to offer, brutal acceleration among them, and a style all its own
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The SLK shows how Mercedes-Benz has refined the luxury roadster experience. It’s available with three powertrains, which emphasize characteristics ranging from frugality to brutality. Yes, just like a trip to Walmart! The lowest-priced SLK250 has a turbocharged four-cylinder and standard six-speed manual transmission that yields 31 mpg highway. On the other hand, the SLK55 AMG must be gagging on the huge 5.5-liter V-8 under its hood: the 415-horsepower car roars from 0 to 60 mph in just 4.5 seconds. Of course the V-8, being equipped with cylinder deactivation and automatic stop/start, tries its best to achieve polite fuel economy. In between, a 3.5-liter V-6 makes 302 horsepower and sends the SLK350 off with a nice growl. The V-6 and V-8 are paired with a seven-speed automatic. The SLK plays twin roles as a suave hardtop coupe and sporty roadster thanks to the power-foldaway top. The optional Airscarf--vents in the seats--delivers warm air around your neck on cool rides. The SLK is as beautiful as other Mercedes-Benzes on the inside when optional wood trim is added. Now add the mbrace2 telematics feature to a host of safety and driver assist features, and techno-wizardry joins other existing characteristics.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. BMW Z4
2. Porsche Boxster
3. Audi TT

Cool Tech:
1. The retractable hard top has the optional Magic Sky Control that lets occupants vary the opacity of the glass panel’s tint.
2. Mbrace2 telematics system adds Internet and remote access capabilities.
3. Adaptive-beam headlights give a better look down the road.

Looks
1. Eighteen-inch wheels are optional on the SLK250 and SLK350.
2. Optional ash or walnut trim replaces standard aluminum in the SLK250 and SLK350.
3. Panorama roof and Magic Sky Control, the variable opacity glass, are optional.

New for 2013
1. The cruise control switches are redesigned.
2. Mbrace2 telematics system adds Internet capability and remote access capability.
3. Adaptive high-beams are options.

title: 2013 Scion FR-S
subTitle: A sporty Scion you can’t help but love
metaTitle: 2013 Scion FR-S Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Scion FR-S here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The FR-S is Scion’s first foray into the land of sports cars, and it is a bold step away from the boxy crossovers that have made a name for Scion in the US. The FR-S is a truly sporty automobile, with responsive handling and a light, speedy feel. It feels and looks like a more expensive car, and with 22 to 25 miles per gallon in the city and 30 to 34 on the highway, it won’t give you driver’s remorse at the gas station. The FR-S’s insides come from Subaru, who are building this car and its twin, the Subaru BRZ, in the same plant. The FR-S is still unmistakably a Scion, with aggressive styling and seemingly endless available accessories and aftermarket add-ons. Despite its cramped rear seats and itsy-bitsy cargo area, the FR-S is easy to love. The car is well balanced which makes for smooth handling, and offers a turbocharged engine with either a six-speed automatic or manual transmission. The FR-S is not content to blend in, either. With colors like Firestorm and Hot Lava, this car is begging to be pulled over. But that only makes it more desirable.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. Honda Civic Si coupe
2. Hyundai Genesis coupe
3. Mazda Miata

Cool Tech:
1. First boxer engine to use Toyota’s direct injection system.
2. Standard Bluetooth connectivity and hands-free phone connectivity.
3. Available Bespoke premium audio system.

Looks:
1. Comes in several bright colors.
2. Distinctive, aggressive styling.
3. Sport seats with contrasting stitching.

New for 2013:
1. All-new model.

title: 2013 Mini Cooper
subTitle: Still the Mini we all love to love
metaTitle: 2013 Mini Cooper Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mini Cooper Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 Mini Cooper is everything a Mini should be. It is, of course, quite small – though the Clubman wagon provides more space than any of Mini’s other models. It is also a treat to drive, with the option of a turbo engine. The interior is attractive and interesting, with unusual features like a very large, center-mounted speedometer and various toggle switches that deliver a shot of nostalgia to anyone who has driven an original Mini. The cabin can come equipped with attractive sport seats and a satellite radio with one-year subscription. With three different bodies (wagon, hard-top, and convertible) and three different trim levels, the Cooper’s options are extensive. Even if you’ve made the big choices, there are what Mini claims to be 10 million customization combinations. All of those choices piled up can make the car a little pricey, even with its relatively low base price. The Mini is so fun and drives so well that you can’t be blamed for splurging a little, and the excellent highway gas mileage of 33 to 37 mpg could save you money in the long run.
Fun-O-meter: 8

Competition:
1. Fiat 500
2. Hyundai Veloster
3. Volkswagen Golf

Cool Tech:
1. Center console with pre-wired iPhone adapter.
2. Standard Bluetooth connectivity.
3. Available Sirius satellite radio.

Looks:
1. Seemingly endless customization options.
2. Attractive and distinctive interior.
3. Fun colors like Spice Orange.

New for 2013:
1. Optional Sirius Satellite radio.
2. Available dual-pane panoramic sunroof.

title: 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom
subTitle: The ultimate in roving comfort
metaTitle: 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: For the price of a large-ish house (depending on where you live) you could own a single, opulent automobile. The Rolls-Royce Phantom is the car for the person who has everything they’ve ever wanted and much, much more. With a beautiful interior and no shortage of space in the back for adult passengers (even Shaq would be comfortable with the Extended Wheelbase version), the car can be customized endlessly, and most buyers choose to take advantage of Rolls-Royce’s bespoke design team. One option turns the Phantom into a theatre, with two rear monitors and a six-disc changer in the glove box. The four-passenger version has room in the backseat for a drink cabinet or cigar humidor. The Phantom is a little slower to 60 mph than the smaller Ghost, but still makes it in under six seconds while preserving Rolls-Royce’s characteristic smooth, quiet ride. Rolls likens the experience of being driven in a Phantom to a  “magic carpet ride.” The Phantom’s recent update brings a new eight-speed automatic transmission, LED lights, and slightly improved fuel consumption. Although, lets face it, if you’re driving around in this thing, you’re not worried about the price of gas.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Bentley Mulsanne

Cool Tech:
1. Headlights automatically adjust light patterns in reaction to driving conditions.
2. Navigation system hides behind an analog clock.

Looks:
1. Exterior design is unmistakably Rolls-Royce.
2. Sumptuous leather interior.
3. Available customization.

New for 2013:
1. Redesigned bumpers.
2. New eight-speed automatic transmission.
3. Improved fuel consumption.

title: 2013 Mini Cooper Countryman
subTitle: Good things come in big(ger) packages.
metaTitle: 2013 Mini Cooper Countryman Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mini Cooper Countryman Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 Mini Countryman doesn’t enter production until November of 2012, but that doesn’t mean you can’t lust after it now. With so much extra space (the Countryman is a whole eighteen inches longer than its brethren) that you can hardly call it mini, the Countryman does a fine job accommodating four people.  The 2012 model reaches up to 35 miles to the gallon on the highway, but the Countryman still offers the performance you expect from a Mini, and has the distinction of being the only car in Mini’s lineup to come with available four-wheel drive. Despite its slightly bulkier body, the Countryman is unmistakable as a Mini. It has an aggressive forward stance and quasi-retro styling, and while the interior styling could be a little sleeker, it is undeniably fun. A center rail that runs the length of the car has colored ambient lighting and sliding rear cup holders. The black dashboard and seats can be accented with a variety of colors including bright red and blue, and the large center-mounted speedometer adds quirk – though it does have the drawback of letting passengers keep tabs on your lead foot.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Honda CR-V
2. Nissan Juke
3. Volkswagen Tiguan

Cool Tech:
1. Available navigation system mounted in over-sized speedometer.
2. Available rear Park Distance Control.
3. Standard HD radio.

Looks:
1. Available bonnet stripes in white or black.
2. Center rail with ambient lighting.
3. Dozens of possible color combinations.

New for 2013:
1. Standard Bluetooth connectivity.
2. New John Cooper Works trim level.
3. Available turbocharged engine.

title: 2013 Mini Cooper Coupe
subTitle: A Mini with a different look
metaTitle: 2013 Mini Cooper Coupe Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mini Cooper Coupe Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Mini Coupe combines the classic lower half of a Mini – bulldog grille and large round headlights – with a very distinctive and somewhat surprising top half that gives the Coupe its speedy look. The front windshield is pushed back, and the roof is lower than other Minis, but the real difference is in the back end. The Mini is already spritely, but this version looks even more quick and maneuverable. Better yet, it actually is quick and maneuverable, and certainly won’t bore you. The John Cooper Works model is the most powerful, but also the most expensive, though with strong fuel economy, you could make up the difference in time.  Like the rest of the Mini family, this two-seater features sport seats and a very large, center-mounted speedometer. The passenger cabin has a trapdoor to the trunk in case you’re transporting something too long for the tight cargo space, and a center armrest can come equipped with a built-in iPhone charging cable. The best thing about the Coupe may be its price. With even the most expensive model barely topping $30,000, the Coupe easily beats the price of luxury competitors but still has spunk.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Audi TT
2. Hyundai Veloster
3. Scion tC

Cool Tech:
1. Impressive gas mileage up to 37 mpg highway.
2. Available armrest with iPhone cable.
3. Navigation and sound system screen mounted in speedometer.

Looks:
1. Distinctive top half and body style.
2. Available racing stripes.
3. Two-tone paint job, one color for body another for roof.

New for 2013:
1. Standard Bluetooth connectivity.
2. Available Sirius Satellite Radio.

title: 2013 Rolls-Royce Ghost
subTitle: If you’ve got the money, you won’t regret the Ghost.
metaTitle: 2013 Rolls-Royce Ghost Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Rolls-Royce Ghost here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Despite being the smallest car that calls itself a Rolls-Royce, you won’t be cramped in this roving palace, especially not if you spring for the Extended Wheelbase edition, which comes with a standard panoramic sunroof. If you’re spending upwards of a quarter of a million dollars on a car, you want it to be perfect, and to that end, Rolls-Royce has engineered an automobile so smooth that you may think you’re floating through the crowds instead of travelling on the same roads as the rest of us. The leather-lined cabin is the last word in comfort and luxury, and with the aggressive, distinctive grille, your status as the owner of a Rolls will be broadcast to everyone you see. If you prefer your luxury a little more personalized, Rolls-Royce has a bespoke department to meet those needs. More than half of Ghosts sold in 2011 had bespoke elements. The Ghost comes with coach doors (suicide doors to the déclassé), for maximum exiting ease to chauffeured passengers. Because despite the Ghost’s impressive performance (0 to 60 mph in less than five seconds) this car may be one of the few that is best enjoyed from the back seat.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. Bentley Mulsanne

Looks:
1. Available two-tone.
2. Panoramic sunroof standard with extended wheelbase version.
3. Soft leather interior.

Cool Tech:
1. Night Vision can recognize pedestrians and prepare the brakes for emergency stopping.
2. Available technology allows trunk to be opened with a leg movement, in case hands are too full to push buttons.

New for 2013:
1. Available perforated leather headliner.
2. Available natural grain leather seats.

title: 2013 Mini Cooper Roadster
subTitle: All the fun of the Mini Coupe, now with the wind in your hair
metaTitle: 2013 Mini Cooper Roadster Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mini Cooper Roadster Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Mini Roadster was all new for 2012, and adding a droptop option to the Coupe was a good move on Mini’s part. Featuring much of the same construction and technology as the Coupe, the Roadster distinguishes itself by losing the somewhat clunky hard top roof of its predecessor and serving up all the undeniable fun of a convertible. The John Cooper Works model is the most powerful, but no matter which engine model you choose the Roadster will deliver. The folding soft-top means the Roadster has even less cargo space than the Coupe and the interior can feel cramped, but the sporty-versus-space tradeoff is typical of convertibles, and the Roadster holds up well to its competition. The bold interior is almost identical to other Minis, with the large central speedometer and navigation system, toggle switches, and sport seats.  The 2013 Roadster will improve upon an already strong base by making the semi-automatic roof and rear windscreen standard, though of course this all comes at a price – specifically, a $1,200 bump from 2012. However, the Mini model of providing affordable performance automobiles rings true, and the Roadster still won’t break the bank.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. Audi TT
2. Mazda MX-5 Miata
3. Volkswagen Eos

Cool Tech:
1. Available Sirius Satellite Radio.
2. Available center armrest with built-in iPhone cable.
3. Available Harmon-Kardon premium sound system.

Looks:
1. Many color combinations, racing stripes.
2. Distinctive Mini interior.
3. Attractive sport seats.

New for 2013:
1. Standard semi-automatic roof.
2. Standard rear windscreen.
3. Standard Bluetooth connectivity.

title: 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom Coupé/ Drophead Coupé
subTitle: If you have a hard time imagining a sexy Rolls-Royce, take a gander at the Coupés
metaTitle: 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom Coupé/ Drophead Coupé Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom Coupé/ Drophead Coupé here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It’s hard to imagine anything more excessively luxuriant than the Phantom, but Rolls-Royce’s engineers have done just that with the Phantom Coupé and Drophead Coupé. The cars are two-door versions of the flagship automobile, and offer many of the same amenities, but with a few stand-out extras. The Coupé offers, one can only assume as a consolation prize for the fixed roof, an optional artificial night sky built in to the headliner. It can also boast an umbrella holder integrated into the frame of the car. It goes without saying that the interior is a study in classic, understated elegance. Seating surfaces are softly grained leather; the trim is attractive wood. The Drophead has an available teak tonneau cover of the type you might be familiar with if you own a vintage yacht. The trunk is also wood-lined, and can extend out until it is a good imitation of a picnic table. As long as you’re splurging, you may as well commission the Rolls-designed picnic basket and hidden refrigerator with wine glass chiller from the bespoke department. A weekend picnic never looked this good.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Bentley Continental G
2. Bentley Continental GTC

Cool Tech:
1. New infotainment system in Drophead with rotary controller.
2. Smartphone cradle.
3. USB and auxiliary inputs for music players.

Looks:
1. Available two-tone exterior.
2. Light-up artificial starry sky in Coupé.
3. Optional teak accessories in Drophead.

New for 2013:
1. New eight-speed automatic transmission.
2. Single piece grille surround.

title: 2012 Mitsubishi I
subTitle: No one will think you’re weird if you hatch from an egg at the next social gathering-as long as the egg is a Mitsubishi i
metaTitle: 2012 Mitsubishi I Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2012 Mitsubishi I Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Your convenience is a key factor to consider when buying a car and with the Mitsubishi i, those dreaded stops at the gas station when you’re running late in the morning are a thing of the past. With a combined driving range of 62 miles per battery charge, this little electric car is ideal for the city dweller whose daily travels consist of driving to the office and the grocery store. Since bigger is synonymous with better here in the States, the American i is longer and wider than its Japanese and European counterparts, but still manages to fit into cramped parking spaces with ease and, with the Rear Park Assist Sensors, is perfect for parallel parking on busy streets. Since the car is 100 percent electric, it does have to be charged on a regular basis. The lithium-ion battery found in your i can be charged overnight using a 120-volt portable charger, but if you’re impatient, you have the option of having a 240-volt charging system installed in your home to charge your car in seven hours. In some areas, it may even be possible to charge your car in less than half an hour at public vehicle charging stations.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Volt
2. Nissan Leaf
3. Smart ForTwo ED

Cool Tech:
1. Rear park assist sensors.
2. FUSE hands-free link system.

Looks:
1. Raspberry (purple) is available as an exterior color.
2. Floor carpet, instrument panel, and door trim made from recycled materials.

New for 2013:
None. Car won’t be in showrooms nationwide until early 2013.

title: 2013 Mitsubishi Lancer
subTitle: With so many options on the 2013 Lancer, you get a near-custom car for a reasonable price
metaTitle: 2013 Mitsubishi Lancer Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mitsubishi Lancer Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The racing-inspired Lancer Evolution has definitely been a favorite in years past, but Mitsubishi has left it as is for the 2013 model year in favor of updating some of the other Lancer trim levels that appeal to a more money-conscious drivers. Now, all-wheel drive is no longer exclusive to the Evolution, but a standard feature on the Ralliart. In fact, many cosmetic features that would generally be bundled in a package, like exterior-matching door handles and mirrors, and interior chrome trim come standard on the many of the trim levels, as do power windows, mirrors, and doors. If that sort of thing isn’t important to you, you’ll be pleased to hear that nearly all safety and security features are standard on all models, making every trim level a safe purchase. With Electric Power Steering, a continuously variable transmission, and a 2.0-liter 4-cylinder engine, the Lancer receives up to 26 mpg city and 34 mpg highway, but don’t expect a quiet ride to go along with the mileage. The Lancer is definitely a fun car to drive and a smart buy, but wind and road noise will be considerable for those who intend to use the car for normal driving rather than amateur racing.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Honda Civic/Si
2. Ford Focus/ST
3. Subaru Impreza/WRX
4. Volkswagen Golf/GTI/R

Cool Tech:
1. Intelligent & Innovative Vehicle Electronic Control system.
2. Six-speed automated manual Twin-Clutch Sportronic Shift Transmission.

Looks:
1. Redesigned alloy wheels.
2. Blacked-out front grille.

New for 2013:
1. Cosmic Blue exterior paint.
2. Plug-in roof carrier.

title: 2012 Ram HD
subTitle: This is what Ram Tough looks like.
promoTeaserSmall: This is what Ram Tough looks like.
promoTeaser: This is what Ram Tough looks like.
metaTitle: 2012 Ram HD Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Ram HD here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2012 Ram 2500 and 3500 are trucks that mean business. In 2012, the big pickups got a six-speed automatic transmission, a boon to those who use the trucks for their intended purpose of hauling heavy stuff. The six-speed manual is also good for heavy loads with its low first-gear ratio, though. A 383-horsepower Hemi V-8 is standard, but a 6.7-liter turbo-diesel six is also available and makes 350 horsepower. The heavy-duty Rams come in eight variants and three cab styles up to the top Laramie Longhorn edition. The Power Wagon version is higher off the ground and has off-road tires, heavy-duty Bilstein shocks, skid plate protection underneath, and other adaptations for off-road excursions. Inside, you’ll find a steering wheel with finger controls, and you can get heated and cooled front seats, heated rear seats, and a heated steering wheel, as well as two-tone upholstery, Sirius backseat TV with three channels to choose from, and Chrysler’s Uconnect multimedia system with ten speakers. There’s in-floor storage, plus, this thing can tow up to a 22,750-pound trailer if you opt for the Max Tow package on the 3500. You might be interested to know that Chrysler finds 50 percent of heavy-truck buyers are planning to use them for work – while 100 percent are planning to use them for fun and leisure. The HD Ram is meant to handle that tractor you need for the field, but also that boat or ATV you want for the weekend.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Silverado HD
2. Ford F-Series Super Duty
3. GMC Sierra HD

Cool Tech Items:
1. Sirius backseat TV.

New for 2013
1. 6’4” bed option on Crew Cab – allows you to have the largest cab with the largest four-door body style and the largest bed option.

title: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Sport
subTitle: A far cry from its larger, sedate cousin the Outlander, the Outlander Sport makes driving a colorful adventure for 2013
metaTitle: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Sport Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Sport Buyer's Guide
