pageElements.text: There’s a reason why the Outlander Sport is Mitsubishi’s best-selling vehicle in North America. With its sticker price of only $19,170, combined mileage of 27 mpg, and ability to seat five adults comfortably, the Outlander Sport is a great car for someone who wants an affordable sport-utility vehicle. The car comes with one engine, a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, but you have the choice of a five-speed manual or a continuously variable transmission (CVT). For the 2013 model year, the Outlander Sport has been redesigned both inside and out with new bumper designs and wheels, as well as new interior fabrics and chrome accents. When you head out to the dealerships, you’ll see the car in two new colors, but you’ll find that it’s particularly eye-catching in Laguna Blue. No matter where you live, we promise that having a cerulean blue car parked in the driveway will make your house look like a tropical getaway! If you like bells, whistles, and tons of lights, you have the option of purchase a wide array of packages to customize your car. The most fun packages are the LED Illumination and Premium packages, which add floor illumination and a panoramic glass roof with mood lighting to make your evening drives a bit more magical.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Hyundai Santa Fe
2. Kia Sportage
3. Mini Countryman
4. Nissan Juke

Cool Tech:
1. HDD navigation system with real-time traffic.
2. Electric Power Steering.
3. Dent-resistant polymer front fenders.

Looks:
1. Panoramic glass roof.
2. Eighteen-inch alloy wheels on all trim levels.

New for 2013
1. Higher grade insulation material for noise reduction.
2. New speakers for better sound.
3. New fabrics for seats.
4. Two-tone exterior color scheme.
5. Two new exterior paint colors: White Pearl and Quick Silver.

title: trucks
metaTitle: trucks
metaDescription: trucks

pageElements.text: Trucks are not just for work anymore. This category includes vehicles for both work and play that have superb carrying ability and are suitable for heavy jobs, whether the kind you do for fun or the kind you get paid for.

title: crossover
metaTitle: crossover
metaDescription: crossover

pageElements.text: This newest category describes a utility vehicle, but one built on a car platform instead of a truck platform. The crossover has more carlike ride and handling and generally better fuel economy than an SUV, and more space than a station wagon.

title: hatchback
metaTitle: hatchback
metaDescription: hatchback

pageElements.text: What hatchbacks have in common is that they have a door that opens up in back for commodious storage and access, making a two-door car into a three-door and a four-door into a five-door. Most are not only easy to pack but easy to afford.

title: convertible
metaTitle: convertible
metaDescription: convertible

pageElements.text: There are convertibles in a wide range of prices and styles, from the Mini Cooper Roadster to the McLaren MP4-12C. Therefore, this category includes cars at a lot of different price points. But if the top comes down, you’ll find it here.

title: 2013 Ram 1500
subTitle: This revised pickup is more than a butch exterior; it has an air suspension and an eight-speed transmission, and it gets 25 mpg on the highway.
promoTeaserSmall: This revised pickup is more than a butch exterior; it has an air suspension and an eight-speed transmission, and it gets 25 mpg on the highway.
promoTeaser: This revised pickup is more than a butch exterior; it has an air suspension and an eight-speed transmission, and it gets 25 mpg on the highway.
metaTitle: 2013 Ram 1500 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Ram 1500 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Chrysler is proud of the fact that its 2013 Ram 1500 full-size pickup truck has been rated at 25 mpg on the highway, best in its cohort. That good news continues with the Ram’s new grille and fascia, a more powerful V-6 engine, and an eight-speed automatic transmission—which has an interesting e-shift dial instead of floor or column shifters. There’s a nod to aerodynamics with grille shutters and an air suspension that has five height settings, including two for off-road applications. The Ram 1500 also has a fuel-saving stop-start system that shuts the engine off when the truck comes to a stop, then restarts it automatically. Add to that a set of low-rolling-resistance tires, another way to improve fuel economy, and you can see how the Ram came up with class-leading mpg. A V-8 engine is still on offer, too, for those so inclined. Inside, the half-ton Ram gets the latest UConnect Access telematics with an 8.4-inch touchscreen; it has a wireless connection built in, which lets you open and start the truck remotely using Internet or smartphone and use voice commands for phone, text, navigation, and music, not to mention hook up to a variety of online services. There’s HD radio as well, a first for the Ram. All that, and a price only one percent higher than the outgoing model at $23,585 including destination for the base model.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Silverado 1500
2. Ford F-150
3. Nissan Titan
4. Toyota Tundra

Cool Tech Items:
1. Air suspension
2. Rotary e-shift dial on eight-speed transmission

Looks
1. New colors for 2013: monotone or two-tone Black Gold, Copperhead, Maximum Steel Metallic, Prairie, and Western Brown.

New for 2013:
1. 6’4” bed option on Crew Cab – allows you to have the largest cab with the largest four-door body style and the largest bed option.

title: indulgence
metaTitle: indulgence
metaDescription: indulgence

pageElements.text: If this is the kind of car you imagine being followed by paparazzi, or parked outside the casino at Monte Carlo, it fits into our Indulgence category. Perhaps you are in a position to buy one of these. Congrats! For the rest of us, it’s always OK to look.

title: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander
subTitle: The minivan of the Mitsubishi family, the Outlander is not to be confused with its similarly-named crossover cousin
metaTitle: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If you want the passenger volume of a minivan, but prefer the off-road capability of a truck or SUV, look no further. The Mitsubishi Outlander (not to be confused with the Outlander Sport) seats five comfortably, but is also available with seating for two additional passengers in the third row. As you chauffeur your children and their friends to and from school and extra-curricular activities, they can enjoy movies in the backseat, thanks to the new Entertainment Package on the Outlander. Meanwhile, you can drive with peace of mind knowing that you’re doing something to help the environment by driving a certified Low Emission Vehicle. You’ll also be giving your wallet a break, since the car gets a combined gas mileage of up to 25 mpg with the basic, 2.4-liter 4-cylinder engine that powers the Outlander ES and SE. It’s a perfectly fine engine, but if you’re a speed demon, it won’t let this 3,400-pound car accelerate very much. By upgrading to a GT model, not only do you get a V-6 engine, but your car will also come equipped with SiriusXM satellite radio, all-wheel control, hill start assist, and Mitsubishi’s FUSE hands-free link system.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Dodge Journey
2. Hyundai Santa Fe
3. Subaru Outback

Cool Tech:
1. Micron air filtration system.
2. Rain-sensing windshield wipers.

Looks:
1. Exterior bears close resemblance to Lancer Evolution.
2. Exterior Package includes rear spoiler and “GT” badge.

New for 2013:
1. Heated side mirror now on ever Outlander at no extra cost.
2. Four new options packages.

title: luxury
metaTitle: luxury
metaDescription: luxury

pageElements.text: We define luxury as a maker’s top-of-the-line product. It has high standard content, and you’ll feel cosseted and pampered when you sit inside.  How expensive it is will vary, but for a car of its type, it will have a extra few dollar signs next to it.

title: sporty
metaTitle: sporty
metaDescription: sporty

pageElements.text: Sportiness is like art: you know it when you see it. This category includes roadsters, coupes, and sedans with temptingly low 0-to-60-mph times.  They range from super hot dream cars to the reasonably accessible. You’d have fun in any of them.

title: family
metaTitle: family
metaDescription: family

pageElements.text: Love Makes a Family, as the slogan goes, but it won’t get your kids to field hockey practice. The Family category includes mid-size or larger vehicles with four doors that seat at least five, in sedan, wagon, minivan, and crossover/SUV body types.

title: Green
metaTitle: Green
metaDescription: Green

pageElements.text: There are many ways to be green these days. This category includes cars that get at least 40 mpg. But beyond fuel efficiency, this category includes alternative-fuel or electric vehicles and PLEV, ULEV, and ZLEV category cars.

title: Adventure
metaTitle: Adventure
metaDescription: Adventure

pageElements.text: Do you have work to do, or play to do, that might involve going off road, carrying loads, or towing? That’s what this category is for. SUVs, utility and off-road vehicles, and crossovers are the body styles you’ll find here.

title: First Car
metaTitle: First Car
metaDescription: First Car

pageElements.text: We define First Car material as a car priced right—close to or under $20,000—for someone just starting out. Ideally it’s also compact, fuel efficient, a safety leader, and equally well suited for an empty nester or just about anyone on a serious budget.

title: sedan
metaTitle: sedan
metaDescription: sedan

pageElements.text: The traditional definition of a sedan is an enclosed passenger vehicle with two rows of seats. It’s an old idea, but it still works for most people and needs. If your car needs to hold five or fewer people, a good choice—compact to full-size—is probably here.

title: 2013 Hyundai Veloster
subTitle: The Hyundai Veloster delivers lots of style and fun but gets some serious street cred with the introduction of a new Veloster Turbo model to the lineup.
metaTitle: 2013 Hyundai Veloster Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Hyundai Veloster with complete specifications and an overview of the features. It's part of the Car Guide at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The asymmetrical Hyundai Veloster, with its one door on the left and two on the right, has been a quirky style leader with a coupe-like profile, but speed freaks sometimes griped about its 138-horsepower base engine. That’s all changed for 2013 with the introduction of a new Veloster Turbo model to the line-up. The turbo model’s new 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder GDI engine churns out 201 horsepower, enough to make this model a serious competitor against the Honda Civic Coupe Si and the Volkswagen GTI. The engine is linked to either a six-speed manual transmission or six-speed automatic transmission. Hyundai expects the Veloster Turbo to return an estimated 38 mpg on the highway. There’s even more excitement on tap, since Hyundai has introduced one of the first matte paint treatments in the industry on the Veloster Turbo. The $1,000 optional matte gray paint is a study in high maintenance, however, since the paint comes with an eleven-page owner’s manual, a wash pad, and microfiber towels. Buyers should be prepared to shell out $4,500 more for the Veloster Turbo than they would for the base car. But they can expect extra features, such as standard heated front seats, a unique front fascia and ground effects. Both the Veloster Turbo and base Veloster handle corners with ease and make living easy in the cabin thanks to clever packaging.
Fun-O-meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Honda Civic/Civic Coupe Si
2. Volkswagen GTI
3. Mini Cooper S/Clubman S

Cool Tech:
1. Pandora Internet radio is integrated into all Velosters.
2. RCA cable and optional 115-volt power outlet in Veloster supports gaming consoles (when parked).

New for 2013:
1. Veloster Turbo model.
2. Matte Gray paint.

title: What Car Seat When?
promoTeaserSmall: Yes, your eight-year-old still needs a car seat. Time to play the Because I Said So card.
promoTeaser: Yes, your eight-year-old still needs a car seat. Time to play the Because I Said So card.
metaTitle: What Car Seat When?
metaDescription: Jean Knows Cars helps you figure out what car seat is right for children at different ages and sizes.

pageElements.text: Maybe I should be putting this on the Confessions page of Jean Knows Cars, but back in the day, I often broke an essential car safety rule with my own children. I let my kids ride in cars without using booster seats before the recommended age and height. Call it peer pressure; none of their friends were still in booster seats. They’re teenagers now, but if I had it to do over again, I would keep them all in boosters until they were four feet, nine inches tall. That’s the size where seatbelts fit properly without a booster--and especially now that air bags are everywhere, it’s the size at which a deploying bag won’t potentially endanger a child who is sitting too low in the vehicle.  Hey, there was a time when nobody used a bike helmet. Now, they’re ubiquitous. We parents need to make booster seats universal in that same way.

images.caption: The ages and stages of child seats, spelled out for you.
Rear facing: not just for infants anymore (Britax B-Safe).
Convertible seat, with five-point harness (Britax Boulevard).
Booster seats are a must until four feet nine (Graco TurboBoosters).

pageElements.text:
Three Stages to the Child Seat Journey

With this story, you'll find a chart showing you the guidelines about child seat use. Notice that it says:
    You need to keep your child facing toward the rear as long as possible. That could be as old as age three, depending on your child's height and weight. It should definitely be until age two.
    Once your child is facing forward, he or she needs to be in a forward-facing child seat for as long as possible before switching to a booster. That means, until that child has honestly outgrown the seat by height and his or her head is sticking above the seatback.
    Then your child, who by now is in mid- to late elementary school, is ready for a belt-positioning booster seat. There are a recent crop of these on the market that are colorful, easy to use, and will position your child so that the seatbelt rests across the upper thighs, not all the way up on his or her stomach, and fits snugly across the shoulder and chest, never behind the back or under the armpit.

Age Twelve, In Booster? Yup!

It's not until a child is at least four feet, nine inches tall that he or she can safely ride in the car without a booster seat. Yes, that means there are twelve-year-olds out there who ought to be in booster seats. Lots of them. And, no matter how much they want to, children under age twelve need to ride in the back seat. It's a safer place in the event of an accident, not to mention that it's more peaceful and easier for you as the driver to concentrate if your kids are in their own zone while you drive.

The federal government maintains an online list of child seat ratings. This ratings list grades specific seats on their ease of use. Use it, and save yourself some trouble in everyday car travel with your child.

title: 2012 Honda CR-V EXL
promoTeaserSmall: Jean explores the redesigned CRV, Honda's "girl cave"
promoTeaser: Jean explores the redesigned CRV, Honda's "girl cave"
metaTitle: 2012 Honda CRV EXL - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Check out Jean's review of the redesigned 2012 Honda CRV EXL, Honda's "girl cave", on JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2012 Honda CR-V EX-L is a redesigned model of the venerable small SUV. It's now in its fourth generation, and this model feels more modern than before. It is lighter, has style and presence, and doesn't feel like a bread van to drive!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/ya-FtYovRuQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Fitted with a 185-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine, the CR-V has a five-speed manual transmission. Interior features on this CR-V include leather-trimmed seats, steering wheel, and shift knob, a Honda navigation system with voice recognition and a rear-view camera, and a seven-speaker stereo system with a subwoofer.
Roof rails, heated door mirrors, and a power moonroof with a tilt feature add a little bit of luxury feel to this compact vehicle.

title: 2013 Ford Shelby GT500
promoTeaserSmall: The Carroll Shelby label means it’s hot and spicy.
promoTeaser: The Carroll Shelby label means it’s hot and spicy.
metaTitle: 2013 Ford Shelby GT500 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Check out Jean's review of the 2013 Ford Shelby GT500 here at Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The Carroll Shelby name is not just badging where I'm concerned. Shelby and I were friends for many years, as you'll hear in my video review of the Shelby GT500. Shelby died last May 10 at the age of eighty-nine. So this year especially, it's fitting that this is the most powerful Mustang ever made--and a major piece of ammunition in the ongoing Camaro vs. Mustang performance-car wars.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/eqPWoiU0Yvc?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The top-of-the-line price for this car is above $68,000 with the addition of options and packages. They include a $3,495 SVT Performance package that bundles Torsen differential, 19-inch forged aluminum front wheels, 20-inch forged aluminum rear wheels, SVT Bilstein cockpit-selectable dampers, unique gearshift knob, and rear springs. A $2,340 electronics package bundles a navigation system, HD radio, and dual-zone climate control. Smaller items include a $375 vehicle cover, a $207 set of illuminated doorsills, $113 each for side scoops, and a $60 ash cup (!). The model you see here also has Le Mans top stripes and rocker stripes, Brembo brakes, a quad exhaust, and a power cloth top.

Standard safety features on the Shelby GT500 include four airbags, anti-lock brakes, traction control, and stability control. A new "productivity screen" in the dash includes an accelerometer that shows the g-force the car is pulling from left to right. You can also track fastest times with the acceleration timer screen.

But what you really want to hear about is power, isn't it? The Shelby GT500 beats the base Mustang by 357 horsepower: it's 662 hp vs. 305 hp. This is not your commuter car, but it could be your track car.

title: 2013 Dodge Dart Rallye
promoTeaserSmall: Italian engine meets classic American car
promoTeaser: Italian engine meets classic American car
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Dart Rallye - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Check out Jean Jennings' review of the 2013 Dodge Dart Rallye here on Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The 2013 Dodge Dart Rallye has the name and thus the heritage of the classic Dart from the Sixties and Seventies. However, it has a very Italian MultiAir turbo engine under its hood, and it also looks very different from the old Dart. This marks Dodge's return to the compact sedan segment that it has been out of since it stopped making the Neon in 2005.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/9BROCPdfSlQ?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

It's also Dodge's way of tapping into retro nostalgia for what was a much loved American nameplate, back in the day. The new Dart shares a platform with Fiat's Alfa Romeo brand, in addition to that engine, and a bonus there is that they are very good with small engine technology.

Standard safety features include anti-lock brakes, traction control, brake assist, and ten air bags, including front and side curtain, driver's-side inflatable knee, and passenger's side inflatable knee bolster bags.

The Dart's competition will be the Toyota Corolla, Chevrolet Cruze, and Hyundai Elantra GLS. The Elantra hits the magic 40-mpg mark, but the Dart doesn't, although it comes close -- topping out at 39 mpg on the highway with the 1.4-liter four-cylinder engine with six-speed manual transmission.

title: 2012 Fiat 500 Sport
subTitle: 2012 Fiat 500 Sport
promoTeaserSmall: Lipstick-red handbag on wheels from Fiat.
promoTeaser: Lipstick-red handbag on wheels from Fiat.
metaTitle: 2012 Fiat 500 Sport - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Watch my review of the 2012 Fiat 500 Sport, and my comparison of the new car with my 1970 Fiat 500L. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Look at the red one in the video, because the one on the right is my own and not the one we're talking about. I know, it's hard to take your eyes off the older Cinquecento, isn't it?
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/pYSlrOkYrz0?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The 2012 Fiat 500 Sport is cool enough that more than 58 million people have looked at the Jennifer Lopez "Papi" music video that it co-stars in. It's a minimalist vehicle along the lines of the Volkswagen Beetle, and of course it's an international icon with more than four million of them having been built between 1957 and 1975. Only, now you can get them here in the United States. Molto bene, grazie!
It's affordable, depending on which model you choose. The Gucci special edition costs $24,200 including destination, but the base 2012 Fiat 500 Pop is priced at $16,200 including destination.

A Cool Tech item on the Fiat 500 is the Eco:Drive app. It collects data about vehicle efficiency. you put a USB memory stick into the USB port on the car, and it gives you a detailed report on environmental performance, including the CO2 emissions level for each trip. It also analyzes the driver's style and provides recommendations for improving fuel economy.
Is it too small for you? The Fiat 500L, a larger version, is coming to the United States next year.

title: 2012 Ford Fiesta SE
promoTeaserSmall: I admire the Fiesta’s zoom—and its low price.
promoTeaser: I admire the Fiesta’s zoom—and its low price.
metaTitle: 2012 Ford Fiesta SE - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: My short, sweet look at the 2012 Ford Fiesta SE here on Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The 2012 Ford Fiesta SE chilled in my driveway, but even a cold snap couldn't cut the level of cuteness of this small car. The Fiesta SE in the video is a sedan, but the hatchback is even cuter.
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/W3yhffOMnco" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

But it's not all about the looks: the Fiesta is fun to drive, even though it is a low-priced subcompact. Both hatchback and sedan versions are powered by a 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine. Fuel economy hits the current holy grail of 40 mpg on the highway if you get the SFE package, which revises the setup of the engine and transmission and includes low-rolling-resistance tires to add fuel economy.

The Fiesta gets some of its fun quotient from the fact that Ford kept the suspension calibration of the European-market Fiesta when bringing this car onto the U.S. market. Its competitors include the Chevrolet Sonic, Honda Fit, Hyundai Accent, and Nissan Versa, so it's a crowded field, but the Fiesta holds its own.

pageElements.text: The Kia Sorento SX AWD you see here is the absolute top-of-the-line Kia SUV. That's okay; if you are going to the back forty of the wilderness or the back forty rows of the opera house parking lot, it will work either way. But the SX AWD is $10,250 more expensive than the base 2013 Kia Sorento LX, which starts at $23,950 including destination.

The Kia Sorento SX AWD made its debut in 2011 and is aimed at giving the Sorento an edgier attitude, according to Kia.
The chief competition for the Sorento comes from the Toyota Venza, the Lexus RX350, and the Ford Edge.

EPA fuel economy on this Sorento SX AWD is 18 mpg in the city and 24 mpg on the highway with the V-6 engine and six-speed automatic transmission. Standard safety features include anti-lock brakes, stability control, and downhill brake control, and there are six air bags.

The Sorento sometimes gets lumped into the crossover/minivan category, but it is an SUV nonetheless. However, it's an SUV with plenty of upgrades to make it stand out in the carpool lane at school, including Infinity surround sound with ten speakers, LED taillights, chrome roof rails, and a set of eighteen-inch mirror finish wheels. The kids in said carpool will appreciate the rear A/C, too.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/J2Ns2ceHEFg?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Here's my take on the Volvo S60 T5 AWD, and on everything it makes me think of.

title: 2012 Jeep Grand Cherokee Altitude 4x4
promoTeaserSmall: Jean parks the Grand Cherokee in the bucolic back forty.
promoTeaser: Jean parks the Grand Cherokee in the bucolic back forty.
metaTitle: 2012 Jeep Grand Cherokee Altitude 4x4 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Check out Jean's review of the 2012 Jeep Grand Cherokee Altitude 4x4 here on Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The mid-size Jeep Grand Cherokee Altitude SUV is the sort of vehicle that most people think of when they think of an SUV, and then some. The Altitude name was chosen from among more than 100,000 entries in a Jeep consumer contest called Name My Ride. The prize was, of course, a $40,000 Grand Cherokee.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/0KUSkUDOS3w" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

This vehicle's Altitude package and options add more than $10,000 to the base price of the Grand Cherokee: a Grand Cherokee Laredo 4x4 starts at $30,120 including destination, and this Altitude costs $42,200 including destination. Of course, for that money it's well equipped, with a $6,600 trim package, a $1,695 Hemi 5.7-liter V-8 engine, an $895 power sunroof, a $495 power liftgate, a $2,200 options package that includes keyless entry and SiriusXM satellite radio, and a $395 UConnect communications system.

Cosmetic touches with the Altitude trim package include a blacked-out exterior with a black glossy grille surround and a platinum chrome mesh grille. The 20-inch wheels and tires add to the look. Leather-trimmed seats (the front seats are heated), plus a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shifter complete the look.
