pageElements.text: The 2012 Mini Cooper S Countryman All4 is a way to have your small car and also have the ability to travel with baggage and companions, such as a dog, for example. This is the practical Mini for those who need more space and more spice than the competition (including the Chevrolet Cruze and Toyota Corolla) can offer. It's got the Kia Soul and Nissan Leaf as competitors, too.
The contrasting roof is a Mini tradition, designed to help the car stand out from the pack at rallies.

The Countryman is 5.5 inches longer than the three-door Mini Clubman. The base car has rear seats that slide back and forth to provide more cargo room, but cargo room is still not great. Fuel economy is decent at a combined 27 mpg for the model with six-speed manual transmission.

You can dress up your Mini, and yourself, with plentiful options such as eighteen-inch wheels, dual-pane sunroof, premium audio, and custom graphics and trim--and for yourself, Mini Countryman boots with a Union Jack design, a parka, a lilac T-shirt with the Mini logo...the list goes on all the way to a wooden chair in racing livery with a Union Jack to match the car.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/E9kIFnASWL0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
The S version of the Countryman is a performance model, with a turbocharged version of the same 181-horsepower engine. You can also get it, as here, with all-wheel drive.

title: 2013 Nissan Xterra
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Xterra is not ashamed to be an old-school SUV.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Nissan Xterra is not ashamed to be an old-school SUV.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Nissan Xterra is not ashamed to be an old-school SUV.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Xterra Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Xterra here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Nissan Xterra does not masquerade as a crossover. It wears its deep SUV roots proudly, a throwback to the days when all sport-utes were beefy and boxy. The Xterra appears set to live another day, since Nissan said the 2013 model will be available early next year, even though specifics will be announced at a later date. It is not expected to get a major revision. The truck-based Xterra is pitched at young, active buyers – and there’s even a built-in first-aid kit. It’s a truly capable off-roader, but suffers from mediocre gas mileage – the bane of traditional SUVs. The Xterra seats up to five and is equipped with a strong 261-horsepower 4.0-liter V-6 engine. The engine can be mated to either a six-speed manual or five-speed automatic transmission. The Xterra’s macho off-road capabilities make it less comfortable and proficient on the road than similarly priced, more refined crossovers. It is built on the same tough F-Alpha platform as Nissan trucks like the Titan and Frontier. The soft suspension on Xterra can make for a bouncy ride on hard pavement, too. The interior is far from luxurious and can’t be hosed out as easily as the cabin in the Jeep Wrangler. Extras on Xterra include a locking rear differential, skid plates, roof-mounted lights, and ceiling hooks in the cargo area.
Fun-O-Meter: 5.5

Competitors:
1. Honda CR-V
2. Jeep Wrangler
3. Suzuki Grand Vitara
4. Toyota 4Runner

New for 2013:
1. Details on the 2013 Xterra will be available at a later date, said Nissan.

title: 2013 Nissan Versa
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Versa is a must-see for those on a quest for the cheapest car.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Nissan Versa is a must-see for those on a quest for the cheapest car.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Nissan Versa is a must-see for those on a quest for the cheapest car.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Versa Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Versa here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It’s anybody’s guess whether the 2013 Nissan Versa sedan will hang onto its title of cheapest car in America, since pricing has not been announced yet. But Versa was the Holy Grail when it came to inexpensive cars last year after Hyundai walked away from the fight over such a title with its redesigned Accent. The base 2012 Versa sedan with a five-speed manual transmission starts at a remarkable $11,770, including a $780 destination charge. Nissan redesigned the Versa sedan for 2012 and it still has appeal for those shopping for the best value. The Versa also comes in a hatchback version, which has yet to undergo a major revision and is a carryover from the 2012 model year. The Versa sedan has much to recommend it since highway fuel economy increases to 40 mpg this year on CVT-equipped models. The sedan is equipped with a 109-horsepower 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine. A Versa sedan with a four-speed automatic transmission is new for 2013. Different trim levels on the sedan also add new features for 2013, including the addition of a rear spoiler on CVT-equipped models and goodies like a remote key fob trunk release on SL models.  In addition to excellent value, the sedan also has a huge trunk and plenty of ride comfort. On the downside, acceleration is acceptable, but not thrilling. If you’re into extreme couponing, stockpiling toilet paper, and penny pinching, the Versa should be on your shopping list.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Sonic
2. Ford Fiesta
3. Honda Fit
4. Hyundai Accent

New for 2013:
1. Versa sedan 1.6 S AT model added with four-speed automatic transmission.
2. SV Convenience Package adds 60/40-split rear seat.
3. SL Tech Package adds RearView Monitor.
4. CVT-equipped models add rear spoiler.
5. SV models add cloth door trim, chromed interior door handles, and painted shift knob, driver’s seat armrest.
6. SL models add Intelligent Key, remote key fob trunk release, sun visor extensions, driver’s seat armrest, and immobilizer.
7. S models add trunk light.
8. Highway fuel economy increases from 38 to 40 mpg on CVT-equipped models.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GL-Class
subTitle: New, second-generation GL keeps the luxury, gains more efficient engines and advanced safety systems.
promoTeaserSmall: New, second-generation GL keeps the luxury, gains more efficient engines and advanced safety systems.
promoTeaser: New, second-generation GL keeps the luxury, gains more efficient engines and advanced safety systems.
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GL-Class Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mercedes-Benz GL-Class here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The second-generation GL-class hitting showrooms in September has a greater number of luxurious appointments than ever while also catching up to the competition in terms of powertrain efficiency. By the time the GL63 AMG arrives in early 2013 as the last of the GL models to debut, buyers will choose from among four engines. A favorite is the turbo-diesel V-6 that makes 240 horsepower, but torque is what you feel first and at 455 lb-ft., it’s making fistfuls of it. The 4.6-liter V-8 is tuned for 362 horsepower in the GL450 4Matic and 429 horsepower in the GL550 4Matic. A seven-speed automatic transmission is common to all models. All-wheel drive is standard throughout the line. The GL gains slightly in length, width, and height. LED daytime running lights and tail lights accent the exterior, which has sleeker bumpers and a new grille. Inside, the driver looks at a colorful instrument display and everyone can enjoy the optional multi-color ambient lighting. Safety is seen to by the inclusion or availability of every sort of electronic abracadabra for lane keeping, curve-hugging, and close-to-curb parking. The standard power liftgate and power-folding third-row seats, with power-folding second row being optional, are desirable conveniences.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. BMW X5
2. Audi Q7
3. Infiniti QX56

Cool Tech Items:
1. Active parking assist scans the curbside for adequate space, guides the vehicle into place, and also has an automatic exit feature.
2. Active curve assist uses an electronically controlled hydraulic system to counteract the body’s tendency to roll on curves.
3. Optional push button capability for offroad driving.

Looks:
1. Panorama sunroof is optional.
2. Optional multi-color ambient lighting graces the interior.
3. LED technology is used for daytime running lights and taillights.

New for 2013:
1. Power-folding second-row seats ease third-row entry and power liftgate eases everyday tasks.
2. Colorful new instrument display is pleasing to driver.
3. New family of engines helps the GL to hold its own against competition.

title: 2013 Mazda CX-9
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda CX-9, the Japanese automaker’s biggest and perhaps best vehicle, gets a facelift for the new model year.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Mazda CX-9, the Japanese automaker’s biggest and perhaps best vehicle, gets a facelift for the new model year.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Mazda CX-9, the Japanese automaker’s biggest and perhaps best vehicle, gets a facelift for the new model year.
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda CX-9 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda CX-9 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Mazda CX-9 gets a makeover for the new model year and now bears a greater family resemblance to the redesigned 2014 Madza 6, which is now poised to be one of the style leaders in the midsize sedan segment. The new look is a welcome change for the CX-9, which hasn’t been tweaked since 2009. The CX-9, which goes on sale late this fall, also gets several new safety features, including forward obstruction warning, lane departure warning, and a high-beam headlight control system. The big Mazda crossover will be equipped with the carryover 273-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 engine and six-speed automatic transmission. Gas mileage in the CX-9 is so-so. The CX-9 returns 17 mpg in city driving and 24 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The CX-9 has big shoes to fill in the Mazda lineup, especially since it’s the end of the road for the Mazda CX-7, which slotted in below the CX-9. The CX-7 is being discontinued in the U.S. Pricing has yet to be announced for the redone CX-9, but it should start at around $30,000. The CX-9 has always won compliments for its communicative steering, car-like responses, and highway stability, along with good interior quality. The third row may be best left for kids, but the CX-9 is set to remain a more stylish alternative to traditional vans and boxier SUVs.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Buick Enclave
2. Chevrolet Traverse
3. Honda Pilot
4. Toyota Highlander

Cool Tech:
1. Forward obstruction warning and high-beam headlight control system are both unusual in this segment.

New for 2013:
1. Revised exterior patterned after 2013 Mazda 6.
2. New safety features, including forward obstruction warning, lane departure warning, and a high-beam headlight control system.

title: 2013 Mazda 2
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda 2 is tiny and thirsty.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Mazda 2 is tiny and thirsty.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Mazda 2 is tiny and thirsty.
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda 2 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda 2 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Mazda 2 has a lot to recommend it, from its long list of standard and safety features, to its decent cabin and cute looks. But the subcompact delivers low fuel economy for such a small car – and doesn’t even hit the magic 40-mpg mark in highway driving. The Mazda 2 also has a steep base price for such a small car, with the base 2013 Sport model starting at over $15,000. An uplevel Mazda 2 Touring model tops $17,000. On the plus side, the Mazda 2 enters the post-modern world with a new USB port, something it lacked in the past. Its refined four-cylinder engine feels livelier than its 100-horsepower rating would suggest, especially when it’s linked to the five-speed manual transmission. A four-speed automatic transmission is optional. There’s no denying that the five-seater is a fun-to-drive city car, but there may be too many compromises for some. The Mazda 2 has a tight back seat and limited cargo room. It lacks the luxury features available in newer subcompacts like the Ford Fiesta. That means no navigation system or heated seats. The Touring model is the way to go if you’re looking for amenities. It includes fifteen-inch alloy wheels, a rear spoiler, chrome exhaust tips, cruise control, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and an audio system with six speakers. The main problem with the Mazda 2 occurs once comparison shopping begins. When you stack it up against its sizeable competition, it’s merely average.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Sonic
2. Fiat 500
3. Ford Fiesta
4. Toyota Yaris

New for 2013:
1. USB port.

title: 2013 Lincoln MKS
subTitle: Latest generation of Lincoln’s flagship is as sleek and smooth as you’re expecting.
promoTeaserSmall: Latest generation of Lincoln’s flagship is as sleek and smooth as you’re expecting.
promoTeaser: Latest generation of Lincoln’s flagship is as sleek and smooth as you’re expecting.
metaTitle: 2013 Lincoln MKS Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lincoln MKS here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Its split-grille face may say Voldemort, but its ride is Nimbus 2000 all the way. The 2013 MKS is a redesigned model that holds on to the smooth, refined ride a Lincoln buyer is looking for while adding lots of high-tech features. Chief among those is Lincoln Drive Control, a system that will let you change almost everything about the driving experience by changing the gear selector between Drive and Sport settings. Smoothness, however, is the main point of this car, as underlined by standard Continuously Controlled Damping, which monitors suspension settings 500 times per second and adjusts the suspension twenty times per second to tweak ride quality. While you’re enjoying that ride, there’s also a new lane keeping system that can warn you of potential accidents by making the steering wheel vibrate. What’s more, it’s customizable as to when alerts are sent and how hard they make the steering wheel vibrate. The MKS’s V-6 engine choices are slightly more powerful this year, with the most fuel-efficient choice being the 3.7-liter V-6 that makes 304 horsepower and provides 18 mpg in town and 27 mpg on the highway. An EcoBoost V-6 on the all-wheel-drive MKS ups horsepower to 365, although it offers slightly lower fuel economy at 17 mpg city and 25 mpg highway. The MKS’s looks are dominated by the new split grille, but updates have also been made to the fenders, headlamps, deck lid, rear end, and exhaust tips. The interior has an all-new instrument panel with MyLincoln Touch, an expanded Sync setup, and many new color schemes. Pricing range from $43,685 for the standard model to $50,685 for the EcoBoost model, including destination.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi A6
2. Infiniti M
3. Lexus GS
4. Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Cool Tech:
1. Lane keeping technology is, as Lincoln puts it, an extra “eye” on the road.
2. Lincoln Drive Control with Drive and Sport settings.

Looks:
1. Fresh exterior color schemes: Ginger Ale, Kodiak Brown metallic tri-coat, and Ruby Red and Smoked Quartz metallic clearcoat.

title: 2013 Lexus LS
subTitle: It’s not every year that Lexus rolls out a new flagship, but this is one of those years.
promoTeaserSmall: It’s not every year that Lexus rolls out a new flagship, but this is one of those years.
promoTeaser: It’s not every year that Lexus rolls out a new flagship, but this is one of those years.
metaTitle: 2013 Lexus LS Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lexus LS here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Lexus made its mark in 1989 with its LS flagship, a full-size luxury sedan that could give the most lavish chariots from Mercedes-Benz and BMW a run for their money, and for less of it. Two dozen years later, Lexus once again is putting the industry on notice with its latest technological tour de force, the all-new, surprisingly emotional 2013 LS. Indeed, the LS460 and the long-wheelbase LS460L have never looked better, their crisp sheetmetal offset by just the right amount of ornamentation. Lexus’s new spindle grille is flanked by high-tech headlamps, the bodysides are clean and straight, and the rear is set off by discreet trapezoidal tailpipes and beautiful taillamps with clever L-shaped LED strips that mimic the Lexus “L.” For 2013, Lexus is offering more flavors of LS than ever: customers with a wild side may opt for the first-ever LS F-Sport model, which rides lower to the ground and dons aggressive front and rear styling and technical-themed interior trim; those in colder climes may be interested in all-wheel-drive LS models; wealthy greenies may consider the pricey hybrid LS600h. Regardless of variety, each LS contains more standard comfort and technology features than we could possibly list, and among the many decadent options are a shiatsu massaging rear seat package, three different wood choices, and a “Climate Concierge” system that automatically activates seat heaters and coolers in addition to the A/C to maintain individual comfort for all passengers. The LS even rides on noise reduction wheels to ensure quietness. Once focused on chasing the luxury leaders in the segment, the 2013 LS proves that Lexus wants to lead.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Mercedes-Benz S-Class
2. Audi A8
3. Jaguar XJ

Cool Tech Items:
1. Sensor-based, multiple-zone Climate Concierge.
2. Available Ottoman Seating Package with shiatsu massage function.
3. Noise reduction wheels.

Looks:
1. New spindle grille and crisply tailored sheetmetal with newfound emotion.
2. Swoopier styling and nineteen-inch wheels on F-Sport model.
3. Available all-LED lighting.

New for 2013:
1. Sporty F-Sport model.
2. Next-generation Remote Touch interface.
3. Several wood options, including matte-brown bird’s-eye maple and eco-friendly bamboo, among others.

title: 2013 GMC Yukon
subTitle: If you think size really does matter (when it comes to SUVs, anyway), GMC has a mega-ute for you.
promoTeaserSmall: If you think size really does matter (when it comes to SUVs, anyway), GMC has a mega-ute for you.
promoTeaser: If you think size really does matter (when it comes to SUVs, anyway), GMC has a mega-ute for you.
metaTitle: 2013 GMC Yukon Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 GMC Yukon here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: While the automotive world seems to be focusing on downsizing and raising fuel economy, the market for full-size SUVs is still vibrant. GMC’s Yukon and its long-wheelbase Yukon XL are getting a little long in the tooth, but they still have few peers in the art of shuttling people, hauling things, or towing trailers—or doing all three simultaneously—with space and style. On the Yukon’s long list of goodies are cool, fold-and-tumble second-row seats with one-handed operation, as well as OnStar and standard third-row seating. A Heritage edition is offered in blue, black, or white, and features twenty-inch wheels, exterior and interior commemorative badging, content upgrades and more, while the Denali model turns the Yukon into a poor man’s Cadillac Escalade. Well, not too poor of a man, as the bling-u-vee model’s signature perforated chrome grille, huge twenty- or twenty-two-inch wheels, upgraded interior materials, Nuance leather upholstery, surround sound audio system, power-release second-row tumbling seats, remote start, rear camera and park assist certainly don’t come for free. But they do add some serious pizzazz to GM’s hardy mega-ute, whether they be standard, XL, or hybrid varieties. Yes, we said “hybrid.” GM builds a hybrid version of this beast, which makes little sense for country folks, but with a third better city fuel economy, urban-dwelling Yukon intenders may want to snatch one up soon as they’re rumored to be on the chopping block when the next-gen model arrives, likely next year.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Suburban
2. Ford Expedition
3. Toyota Sequoia

Cool Tech Items:
1. Two-mode hybrid model with 33 percent better city fuel economy.
2. Slight fuel economy improvement with cylinder deactivation.
3. Yukon XL offered as heavy duty model.

Looks:
1. Unique wheels, upgraded interior on swan song Heritage edition.
2. Chrome-heavy exterior trim, luxury-laden interior on fancy schmancy Denali model.
3. Aero accents, H-Y-B-R-I-D decals on Hybrid model.

New for 2013:
1. Powertrain grade braking in normal transmission mode (versus tow/haul mode).
2. Champagne Silver exterior color.

title: 2013 GMC Sierra
subTitle: A very good truck that’s about to be replaced by an even better one.
promoTeaserSmall: A very good truck that’s about to be replaced by an even better one.
promoTeaser: A very good truck that’s about to be replaced by an even better one.
metaTitle: 2013 GMC Sierra Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 GMC Sierra here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: GMC is poised to launch an all-new Sierra pickup in 2013, information about which was not available at the time of this writing. In the meantime, dealers have stockpiled many 2012 Sierras that they may be eager to move. Among them should be a few “Heritage Edition” models rolling on chunky six-spoke, twenty-inch wheels, with rear fender liners, chrome trim bits, rear park assist, rear camera, adjustable pedals, and commemorative embroidery. Hybrid Sierras will continue through the 2013 model year using the current body style, still achieving 33 percent better city fuel economy than the standard Sierra and 23 percent better mileage overall. Heavy-duty Sierras, which also continue relatively unchanged through 2013, gain a new “bi-fuel” version of the 6.0-liter V-8 that allows them to run on compressed natural gas (if available), or gasoline. GM’s venerable 6.6-liter Duramax V-8 is on the options list, too, in case you have any houses that need to be towed somewhere. And as before, gussied-up Denali models of both light- and heavy-duty Sierras have been offered for people who want to live it up while hauling a load. All that said, while the Sierra is a fine truck, it’s not the freshest anymore. Watch this space for more information on the next-generation Sierras in coming months, with next-gen HD models expected to arrive within a year of the standard model’s arrival.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Nissan Titan
2. Toyota Tundra
3. Ford F-Series

Cool Tech Items:
1. New “bi-fuel” 6.0-liter V-8 compatible with gasoline and compressed natural gas.
2. Eighty-gig hard drive-based infotainment system with navigation available on HD models.

Looks:
1. Chrome-drenched Denali crew cab models offered on both standard and HD.
2. Larger grille and tall, louvered hood on HD model.
3. Embroidered seats, twenty-inch wheels, chrome trim, convenience items on 2012 Heritage Edition (light-duty models).

New for 2013:
1. Bi-fuel CNG-compatible 6.0-liter V-8 (HD models only).
2. Heritage Edition (late 2012 models).
3. Sonoma Red and Heritage Blue exterior colors (n/a on Denali).

title: 2013 SRT Viper
subTitle: Charming the snakes: Dodge’s phenomenal Viper returns as an SRT model, and it’s (a little) friendlier this time
promoTeaserSmall: Charming the snakes: Dodge’s phenomenal Viper returns as an SRT model, and it’s (a little) friendlier this time
promoTeaser: Charming the snakes: Dodge’s phenomenal Viper returns as an SRT model, and it’s (a little) friendlier this time
metaTitle: 2013 SRT Viper Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 SRT Viper here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Destined to make it onto more bedroom walls of adolescent boys than any American car, save perhaps the Chevrolet Corvette, is the all-new SRT Viper. Still a monstrously powerful supercar but slightly less obnoxious than the wily Vipers of yore, the 2013 Viper shed its fiberglass skin in favor of more elegant, organically shaped carbon fiber and aluminum body panels that save weight while allow for far more consistent body gaps. The Viper also shed the Dodge brand name in favor of Chrysler’s Street and Racing Technology—a.k.a. SRT—brand name. Base Vipers gain infinitely more refined interiors with a customizable instrument screen and far more creature comforts (and alas, the floorboards will no longer melt your tennis shoes). The even sharper-edged (and $23,000 more expensive!) GTS model receives additional leather trim, an adjustable suspension, upgraded brakes and more. The re-imagined exterior lighting includes LED running lamps and taillamps, but the overall look is pure Viper, including the double-bubble roof (ostensibly for helmet clearance). An 8.4-liter V-10 still resides under the hood, this time with new fewer than 640 horsepower (not sure how much that is in snakepower, but it’s certainly a lot). Missing from the lineup at this point is a roadster model; the 2013 model year appears to be for coupes only. Don’t expect Dodge—er, SRT—to stay out of the convertible business for long, though. After all, Viper drivers, of all people, love to be seen.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Corvette ZR1
2. Jaguar XKR/XKR-S
3. Porsche 911

Cool Tech Items:
1. Seven-inch, full-color, customizable instrument cluster.
2. 8.4-inch touch-screen infotainment and connectivity system.
3. Active suspension with “Street” and “Track” modes for GTS.

Looks:
1. BiXenon headlamps with LED running lights and snakeskin texture.
2. Track-ready GTS model with larger hood vents, additional leather inside.
3. Lightweight wheels, sticky tires, upgraded brakes and suspension on GTS Track package.

New for 2013:
1. Carbon fiber and aluminum body.
2. Coupe only (so far).
3. Massively upgraded interior.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Volt
subTitle: Bzzzt! The long-awaited Volt is now a standard member of the automotive mainstream.
promoTeaserSmall: Bzzzt! The long-awaited Volt is now a standard member of the automotive mainstream.
promoTeaser: Bzzzt! The long-awaited Volt is now a standard member of the automotive mainstream.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Volt Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Chevrolet Volt: Learn more about the 2013 model of GM's groundbreaking hybrid. The details are at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Chevrolet’s Volt five-door hatchback EV, so long in the making and so eagerly awaited only a few years ago, is now in its second model year and has become a solid, if less than captivating, citizen in the Chevrolet lineup.  Yes, it runs only thirty-eight miles on electric power alone—which is three miles more than last year’s model—and its rear seat is best suited for children, but consider the fuel economy: 98 mpg equivalent, in the EPA’s parlance for electric vehicles. The range-anxious will appreciate a new Hold Drive mode—added to the Volt’s Normal, Sport, and Mountain drive modes—which helps conserve battery life. On gasoline-only power, fuel economy is 37 mpg. Its fuel economy is aided by a set of Goodyear Fuel Max low-rolling-resistance tires, but they don’t appreciably hurt the ride quality. The Volt will hit a top speed of 100 mph—perhaps not the consideration uppermost on Volt buyers’ minds, but still—and, probably a number more of interest, it has a ten-to-sixteen-hour recharge time using standard household current.  Option packages add such amenities as heated front seats, perforated leather seating and steering wheel, a rear-view camera, and parking sensors at front and back. Lane departure warning and forward collision alert are other options, as is Chevrolet’s MyLink system with navigation. All that, and a range between fillups of 382 miles, if you take both the battery life and the fuel tank’s capacity into account.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Nissan Leaf
2. Toyota Prius

Cool Tech Items:
1. Hold Drive mode to help conserve the battery.

Looks:
1. Perforated leather seating and steering wheel.
2. Body-color roof and liftgate.
3. Pebble Beige color cloth or leather seating new for 2013.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Traverse
subTitle: The twenty-first century’s station wagon for the upwardly-mobile mobile family.
promoTeaserSmall: The twenty-first century’s station wagon for the upwardly-mobile mobile family.
promoTeaser: The twenty-first century’s station wagon for the upwardly-mobile mobile family.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Traverse Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Traverse here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Traverse is not your everyday seven- to eight-passenger SUV. Its attractively curvaceous body style and well-appointed interior set it apart from the basic family vehicle, and it’s priced starting at $31,000, so for a vehicle of its size and type, it’s attractive financially, too. For 2013, the Traverse gets a mild makeover inside and out. Part of the newness includes chrome accents and an updated center stack, as well as eight-way passenger seats and adjustable headrests. There’s also—first on the market—a front center air bag to protect people in the front seat in the event of a side collision. The third row of seats is split folding and is best left to the kids. In the second row, you can elect to have a bench seat to increase total seating capacity to eight. SUV-style options include a rear-view camera, Bose sound, a power liftgate, and a navigation system. Do any of those really sound like things you could live without? In this kind of vehicle, maybe not!
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Ford Expedition
2. GMC Yukon
3. Nissan Armada
4. Toyota Sequoia

Cool Tech Items:
1. Second row has SmartSlide that allows ease of access to third row with one hand—even by children.

Looks:
1. Upgraded interior with soft-touch instrument panel and door surfaces.
2. Ambient cabin lighting (optional).

New for 2013:
1. Revised appearance with “power dome hood,” chrome accents, redesigned taillamps and liftgate.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Tahoe
subTitle: Suburban’s smaller sibling has the same big Chevy heart, just not as big a footprint.
promoTeaserSmall: Suburban’s smaller sibling has the same big Chevy heart, just not as big a footprint.
promoTeaser: Suburban’s smaller sibling has the same big Chevy heart, just not as big a footprint.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Tahoe Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Tahoe here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Tahoe is two feet shorter than the Suburban, and it also comes in a hybrid version. But there are many ways in which the two are similar: starting with the 5.3-liter engines they share, continuing with the number of people they seat (up to nine), and how it looks inside.  It’s still a full-size SUV, even if it’s not the fullest-size you can get from the bowtie brand. It can tow up to 8,500 pounds, carry cargo up to 108.9 cubic feet, and still get 21 mpg on the highway. That latter figure is courtesy of Active Fuel Management on the 5.3-liter V-8 and a standard six-speed transmission. Then there’s the two-mode hybrid, which delivers 20 mpg in town and 23 mpg on the highway in either rear- or four-wheel-drive versions, which GM says is tops for the full-size utility segment. Considering its size (it seats up to eight) and its 332 horsepower, that is not bad—even if it’s not quite the configuration you might picture when you think “hybrid.” A Bose nine-speaker sound system (also available on the standard Tahoe LT) and a rear-vision camera are the icing on the hybrid’s cake.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Ford Expedition
2. GMC Yukon
3. Nissan Armada
4. Toyota Sequoia

Cool Tech Items
1. Rear DVD entertainment system with third-row DVD screen, part of the Sun, Entertainment and Destinations package.
2. Power retractable assist steps an option on LTZ model.
3. Heated power outside mirrors with integrated signal indicators, curb tilt, and ground lights (optional on LT, standard on LTZ).

Looks:
1. Three new metallic paint colors; Champagne Silver now, Concord and Blue Ray coming later in model year.
2. Z71 Off Road appearance package has eighteen-inch aluminum wheels, color-keyed wheel flares, chrome tubular assist steps, a chrome front grille insert, among other things.

New for 2013:
1. Powertrain grade braking now available when transmission is in normal mode (doesn’t have to be on tow/haul setting).

title: 2013 Chevrolet Suburban
subTitle: There ain’t nothing like the real thing.
promoTeaserSmall: There ain’t nothing like the real thing.
promoTeaser: There ain’t nothing like the real thing.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Suburban Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Suburban here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Suburban is sui generis: not a minivan or a work truck, not an SUV, not a station wagon. Call it the Shaquille O’Neal of vehicles: it’s a behemoth, yes, but one that overflows with personality and charm despite its eighteen-plus-foot length.  Who doesn’t like the Suburban? It has not been the butt of hostility the way the Hummer, for example, has been. And even though there has been a Suburban on the market for nearly eight decades, no committee has turned it into a Suburbanette or taken it off the job it is on earth to do: haul people and stuff capably. If you’re shopping for one, know that you can choose from three V-8 engines, and in half-ton or three-quarter-ton versions. Active Fuel Management is on hand to bust that eight down to four cylinders when cruising, to save on gasoline, and E85 can be used. But you don’t care about that as much as two other numbers: how much cargo, and how many people? The answers are: 138 cubic feet, and nine people. There are also comfort features on board, including a second- and third-row DVD system, touchscreen navigation, a backup camera, and heated seats in the front two rows. So what are you waiting for? Saddle up, remember to fuel up-- and off you go.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Lincoln Navigator
2. Ford Expedition
3. GMC Yukon XL
4. Nissan Armada

Cool Tech Items:
1. Rear DVD entertainment system with third-row DVD screen, part of the Sun, Entertainment and Destinations package.

Looks:
1. Three new metallic paint colors; Champagne now, Concord and Blue Ray coming later in model year.

New for 2013:
1. Powertrain grade braking now available when transmission is in normal mode (doesn’t have to be on tow/haul setting).

title: 2013 Chevrolet Spark
subTitle: Mini Chevy is cute, cute, cute, but its fuel economy is not as big as it is small.
promoTeaserSmall: Mini Chevy is cute, cute, cute, but its fuel economy is not as big as it is small.
promoTeaser: Mini Chevy is cute, cute, cute, but its fuel economy is not as big as it is small.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Spark Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Spark here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It’s a car for a small planet: the Chevrolet Spark is tiny and adorable. It also has a five-door hatchback body style with a reasonably sized back seat area, making it an unusual choice in the minicar category. Priced starting at just under $13,000, it’s a logical alternative to cars like the Fiat 500. Unfortunately, the Spark doesn’t astonish with great fuel economy: it makes 28 to 32 mpg in town and tops out at 38 mpg on the highway. Since 40 mpg has become the number to beat, that’s not a brilliant figure, especially considering the Spark only offers 84 horsepower from a 1.2-liter four-cylinder engine. Five-speed manual and four-speed automatic transmissions are available, and despite its diminutive size, the Spark has a grown-up set of ten standard airbags. Chevrolet is aiming this, its first U.S.-market minicar, at city dwellers, which explains in part why it offers MyLink information and entertainment with a seven-inch color screen, Bluetooth streaming audio, and Pandora and Stitcher compatibility. It may not be the greenest of the small cars, but it’s a pretty colorful choice for a starter car.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Fiat 500
2. Scion iQ
3. Smart ForTwo

Cool Tech Items:
1. MyLink Radio with seven-inch color touchscreen.
2. BringGo embedded GPS navigation app (late availability).

Looks:
1. Five-door body looks like a three-door because door handles are integrated into the C-pillar area.
2. Salsa Red, Jalapeno, Denim, Lemonade (late availability) and Techno Pink are among the color choices.

New for 2013:
1. New model for U.S. and Canada.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Silverado
subTitle: Rock-steady pickup from the Like a Rock brand.
promoTeaserSmall: Rock-steady pickup from the Like a Rock brand.
promoTeaser: Rock-steady pickup from the Like a Rock brand.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Silverado Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Silverado here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Silverado pickup truck, like the workers who will buy it, is nothing if not versatile. It can be configured in an amazing number of variations, including five trim levels, a choice of three bed lengths up to eight feet, three cab sizes up to crew cab, rear- or four-wheel drive, and five V-6 or V-8 engines—plus there’s even a hybrid. Fuel economy may not be what a full-size pickup is about, but the Silverado 1500 Hybrid can tow 6,100 pounds while getting 23 mpg on the highway—the eco equivalent of bringing home the bacon and frying it up in a pan, we guess. There’s also a conventionally V-8-powered Silverado, the XFE, that offers 22 highway mpg thanks to “aerodynamic enhancements.” New for 2013 is powertrain grade braking for models with the six-speed automatic transmission, which downshifts the transmission to cool down the brakes on those long downhill stretches. Also, there are two new metallic exterior colors, Deep Ruby and Blue Topaz. But decorative touches are a minor point. GM leaves no doubt about what kind of buyer it’s aiming this truck at, using terms like “broad shouldered” and “chiseled”—to describe the truck, not the customer, but chances are, the descriptors fit both.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford F-150
2. GMC Sierra
3. Ram 1500
4. Nissan Titan

Cool Tech Items:
1. Optional rear backup camera.
2. Powertrain grade braking downshifts transmission on downhill driving to save the brakes.

Looks:
1. Chrome bumper standard on three trim levels.
2. Grab-style door handles good for glove wearers.

New for 2013:
1. Ruby Red and Blue Topaz metallic paint colors added.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Silverado HD
subTitle: Nothing says “Yes, we can” like this kind of heavy-duty work truck.
promoTeaserSmall: Nothing says “Yes, we can” like this kind of heavy-duty work truck.
promoTeaser: Nothing says “Yes, we can” like this kind of heavy-duty work truck.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Silverado HD Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Silverado HD here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Duramax twin-turbocharged diesel 6.6-liter V-8 power: it’s every bit as macho as it sounds, and that’s what powers the Chevrolet Silverado HD work truck. We at Jean Knows Cars don’t generally give a lot of thought to the finer points of torque, but consider the Silverado HD’s 765 pound-feet of torque, which is what gives this engine its massively competent trailer-toting strength. It’s also the reason that this truck gets a heavy-duty Allison automatic transmission—which can be shifted manually by the driver when the going gets dicey. In addition to that 397-horsepower V-8 diesel, there’s a choice of bi-fuel compatible or standard V-8 power, still nothing to sneeze at. There are even heavier-duty 2500HD and 3500HD versions, three-quarter-ton and one-ton, respectively. If you are interested in a truck that can run on compressed natural gas (CNG), get the extended-cab version of the 2500HD. Like its more normal-sized sibling, the regular Silverado, the HD comes in Ruby Red and Blue Topaz metallic exterior paint for 2013. But this truck is all about strength, not beauty: you can tow up to 23,100 pounds, depending on the model. Now that’s empowerment.
Fun-O-Meter: 3

Competitors:
1. Ford Super Duty
2. GMC Sierra Heavy Duty
3. Ram Heavy Duty

Cool Tech Items:
1. Integrated exhaust brake lets you use cruise control while hauling.

Looks:
1. Spring-loaded EZ-Lift tailgate (optional).
2. Heated, power-adjustable “camper style” outside mirrors (optional).
3. Chrome Essentials package on LT and LTZ adds chrome to exhaust, door handles, mirror caps, aluminum wheels, etc.

New for 2013:
1. Ruby Red and Blue Topaz metallic paint colors added.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Malibu
subTitle: All-new model, available in hybrid or traditional four-cylinder flavors.
promoTeaserSmall: All-new model, available in hybrid or traditional four-cylinder flavors.
promoTeaser: All-new model, available in hybrid or traditional four-cylinder flavors.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Malibu Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Malibu here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Chevrolet completely redid the Malibu for 2013, giving it a more modern appearance, widening it for more interior room and trunk space, and going with the ecological flow by offering it as a hybrid. This mid-size sedan is available either as a four-cylinder/electric hybrid or with a standard or turbocharged four-cylinder engine, all of which are paired with a fuel-friendly six-speed automatic transmission. The hybrid version, called the Malibu Eco, has General Motors’ eAssist lithium-ion battery setup, giving the sedan a 37-mpg highway fuel economy rating. That’s impressive, but not the best you can do in today’s eco-competitive marketplace. The Eco model has been dressed up with metallic, chrome, or wood accents in the cockpit, plus ice blue ambient lighting and—surprise—a swiveling radio face that hides a six-inch-deep secret storage compartment. Chevrolet calls this “the quietest Chevrolet in history,” asking you to notice its use of sound-reducing and sound-absorbing materials inside the Malibu. While you’re enjoying the quiet, note the trendy dual cockpit and the presence of the Chevrolet MyLink information and entertainment system, standard on the Eco model. Even General Motors admits that the mid-size sedan segment is “vanilla,” but the company has worked hard to position the Malibu, now in its eighth generation, as a modern contender.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Honda Accord
2. Hyundai Sonata
3. Toyota Camry
4. Volkswagen Passat

Cool Tech Items:
1. Eco model has eAssist, GM’s lithium-ion battery system.
2. Regenerative braking with Eco model provides up to fifteen kilowatts of energy to charge battery.

Looks:
1. Dual cockpit not to everybody’s taste, but different.
2. “Powerdome” hood a little aggressive for a mid-size sedan!

New for 2013:
1. All-new four-cylinder engine.
2. More aerodynamically correct body style.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Impala
subTitle: Swan song for the current version as an all-new design waits in the wings.
promoTeaserSmall: Swan song for the current version as an all-new design waits in the wings.
promoTeaser: Swan song for the current version as an all-new design waits in the wings.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Impala Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Impala here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The spacious six-seater Impala sedan has been a stalwart in its segment for half a century. This year is the last for the current model, since Chevrolet has completely redesigned the Impala for 2014. That will present buyers of full-size sedans with a sleeker, much more modern-looking product. In the meantime, the current Impala will stick around in its current guise for 2013. Part of its appeal this year will be a Luxury Edition package that includes heated leather front seats, a premium Bose audio system with eight speakers, a universal home remote control, and other quality-of-life features. The uplevel LT and LTZ models will be available in a new Crystal Red Tintcoat color to help the old Impala go out with a flourish. The 2013 Impala comes with a 3.6-liter V-6 that makes 300 horsepower, coupled to a six-speed automatic transmission. Despite its old-school size and shape, this sedan gets up to 30 mpg on the highway. The upcoming 2014 model will be available with a choice of three new engines, two four-cylinders (one of which is a mild hybrid) and a V-6, to go with its new look. It’s scheduled to come out in early 2013. The Chevrolet Impala may not get anybody’s heart racing, but it fills the bill just fine if what you want is a traditional big sedan. Get a good deal on the 2013, or look forward to the upcoming 2014? Decisions, decisions.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Chrysler 300
2. Dodge Charger
3. Ford Taurus

Cool Tech:
1. Adaptive cruise control (coming on 2014 model): senses traffic ahead and adjusts vehicle’s speed; first time this will be used on a Chevrolet product.
2. Collision mitigation braking (coming on 2014 model): alerts driver when a crash is likely; can brake to avoid the crash if driver doesn’t react in time.

New for 2013:
1. Luxury Equipment package dresses up the final year for current product.

title: Victoria Beckham Has Designs on the Auto Industry
subTitle: Style icon puts her touch on a special-edition Range Rover
promoTitle: Victoria Beckham Has Designs on the Auto Industry
promoTeaserSmall: An especially stylish Range Rover Evoque from Victoria Beckham
promoTeaser: An especially stylish Range Rover Evoque from Victoria Beckham
metaTitle: Jean Knows Cars admires Victoria Beckham and her foray into the auto industry with a Range Rover Evoque special edition.
metaDescription: Victoria Beckham has designs on the auto industry. Jean Knows Cars admires Victoria Beckham's special edition Range Rover Evoque.

pageElements.text: When the Range Rover Evoque Special Edition hits the market in October, it is expected to become an instant collector’s item, thanks to the work of fashion designer and cultural icon Victoria Beckham--yes, that Victoria Beckham of Posh and Becks fame.

The Evoque Special Edition bears Beckham’s unmistakable design stamp of edgy yet understated elegance. She worked on the cosmetic elements of the Evoque in collaboration with the Land Rover Design team, which apparently was mesmerized by the outfit she wore when they first met.

Beckham was wearing “dark clothes and no jewelry apart from a rose gold man’s watch,” said Gerry McGovern, Land Rover director of design. The watch became a sort of talisman for the team, inspiring the look of the car inside and out.

The Evoque Special Edition features such touches as hand-finished matte exterior paint and 20-inch gloss black forged alloy wheels with rose-gold accents, along with rose-gold-plated interior touches. The rose-gold accents are right in line with a hot trend in fine jewelry.
Beckham’s Evoque also gets mohair floor mats, a custom luggage set and a hand-sewn leather portfolio for the owner’s manual, signed by the fashion designer.
“I like that it feels luxurious, but also has quite a classic edge to it as well as a contemporary feel,” said Beckham.

The New York Times credits Beckham, a former member of the British pop group the Spice Girls, with making “strong clothes for strong women.” While she is not the first female fashion designer to turn her attention to cars — Dana Buchman tinkered with the 2007 Cadillac SRX — Beckham is the most high-profile color-and-trim artist in the auto industry at this point.

“Working with Victoria, the intention was not to change the fundamental architecture  and design of the Evoque,” said McGovern. “We wanted to create a special edition that extends its character in a new direction through understated, restrained color and detail changes.”
It makes us wonder, why don't they let Victoria Beckham design a Range Rover from top to bottom before some other auto company snaps her up?

title: 2013 Chevrolet Equinox
subTitle: Another crossover that’s not really just another crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: Another crossover that’s not really just another crossover.
promoTeaser: Another crossover that’s not really just another crossover.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Equinox Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Equinox here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It’s hard to remember a time when crossovers weren’t all over American roads; they have become so well established that it’s harder to notice them or tell them apart. This one is no exception; it gets a more powerful V-6 engine for 2013, without losing out on fuel economy—24 mpg on the highway—but otherwise it’s the tried-and-true smaller crossover that it has been for several years already. The interior is dependable and modern-looking, with blue ambient lighting and a wraparound dashboard with an upright center stack. The exterior has a sleek front end; its raked windshield and sweeping headlamps turn the Equinox into the anti-box. The base four-cylinder engine is no powerhouse, but it can get 32 mpg on the highway if you use the transmission-adjusting Eco mode. For those who want to use their crossover for towing, or just want more power, the newly added 3.6-liter V-6 makes 301 horsepower while adding 37 horsepower over last year’s smaller V-6 engine and, as previously mentioned, with no loss in fuel economy. This front-wheel-drive five-seater may not break any new ground in style or substance, but it is a good choice for anyone seeking a moderate amount of both attractiveness and versatility in a reasonably priced package.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Ford Escape
2. Honda CR-V
3. Hyundai Santa Fe
4. Toyota RAV4

Cool Tech:
1. Eco mode on four-cylinder engine.
2. Lane departure warning system (option on top LTZ model).
3. New suspension package for model with 3.6-liter V-6 engine.

Looks:
1. Power liftgate.
2. New Champagne Silver Metallic exterior color coming later in model year.

New for 2013:
1. FE2 suspension to go with new, larger V-6 engine.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Cruze
subTitle: Chevrolet’s strong contender in the small-car segment adds techno interest for 2013.
promoTeaserSmall: Chevrolet’s strong contender in the small-car segment adds techno interest for 2013.
promoTeaser: Chevrolet’s strong contender in the small-car segment adds techno interest for 2013.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Cruze Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Cruze here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Cruze name may not have the historical cachet in the small-car segment that is enjoyed by such competitors as the Honda Civic, but it has a lot going for it. For one thing, it’s peppy, with good highway smoothness and well-designed suspension. You can get it with a turbocharged 1.4-liter engine or a 1.8-liter engine with variable valve timing that makes 138 horsepower and yields 36 mpg on the highway. Beating that is the Cruze Eco model, which has lighter suspension parts and low-rolling-resistance tires, taking top honors for a non-hybrid at 42 mpg highway for the manual-transmission model. Chevrolet has also upped the technology ante on what was already a pretty great interior. Chevy’s MyLink information and entertainment system is standard on most versions, offering Bluetooth streaming audio and voice recognition. There are also two new audio systems on offer, including one with GPS navigation and a seven-inch color touchscreen. Perhaps the most appreciated 2013 addition is an optional Enhanced Safety package with park assist, blind-spot alert, and rear cross-traffic alert systems. To dress up your Cruze, there’s an RS appearance package with a rear spoiler, rocker moldings, an upgraded fascia, and chrome instrument panel accents instead of the standard silver. Top it off with a sliding power sunroof on LT and LTZ trim levels.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Honda Civic
2. Ford Focus
3. Hyundai Elantra
4. Mazda 3

Cool Tech:
1. MyLink information and entertainment system.

New for 2013:
1. MyLink standard on three trim levels.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Corvette
subTitle: Six decades of wind in the hair and a song in the heart.
promoTeaserSmall: Six decades of wind in the hair and a song in the heart.
promoTeaser: Six decades of wind in the hair and a song in the heart.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Corvette Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Corvette here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Yes, it has been sixty fun-filled years since the first Chevrolet Corvette hit American roads. Making no concessions to this late-middle-age number, in 2013 Chevrolet is selling the fastest convertible in the history of the bow-tie brand, the 427 convertible. With its carbon fiber body parts and 505-horsepower 7.0-liter V-8, it’s pretty much a droptop version of the Corvette Z06. GM is calling it a Collector Edition, so keep that in mind. The Z06 coupe comes in a limited Carbon edition that has many of the styling features of its more powerful ZR1 sibling. Speaking of the ZR1, the top Corvette’s supercharged V-8 makes 638 horsepower and lets the Vette go north of 200 mph. The big story for 2013, in addition to the last year the current-generation C6 Corvette is in production, is the Sixtieth Anniversary appearance package. It’s a pretty classy-looking Arctic White exterior with two shades of blue on the leather-wrapped interior. An optional graphics package shouts a bit more loudly about the anniversary, and naturally there is badging inside and out to make this package more special. Corvette buyers looking for something a little less pricey may prefer the lower-frills Grand Sport, still with a sub-four-second 0-to-60-mph time close to that of its pricier stablemates. Add to that the base coupe and convertible models, and you’ll see that there’s a Corvette at price points just above $50,000 to a bit over $100,000.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Audi R8
2. Lotus Evora
3. Porsche 911

Cool Tech Items:
1. Carbon fiber body panels, including fenders and hood, on the 427 convertible.
2. Magnetic ride control.

Looks:
1. Sixtieth Anniversary Design package: two-tone blue seating, racing stripes.
2. Lightweight Cup wheels on 427 convertible.

New for 2013:
1. 427 convertible is new model.

title: Time to Decompress!
subTitle: Optimize your music in the car
promoTeaserSmall: Optimize your music in the car for the very best sound quality from your portable music device.
promoTeaser: Optimize your music in the car for the very best sound quality from your portable music device.
metaTitle: Time to Decompress! - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Time to Decompress! Learn how to optimize the sound of music and overcome compression issues on your portable devices at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I’m a jazz aficionado, a car geek, a food lover, and a goofy mom. I'm lucky enough--or foolish enough--to be able to turn most of my avocations into something resembling a vocation. Except for motherhood, but that's its own reward, right?

I was a record store geek back when there were record stores, and worked at the venerable (and late, lamented) Schoolkids' Records in Ann Arbor through college, while spinning jazz records at WEMU to the taxi drivers, barflies and night owls who listened during the wee hours. I then spent a dozen years as the corporate jazz buyer for the Borders Books & Music chain, a job that even in hindsight seems too good to be true.  After the music business--and Borders-imploded, I pursued another passion and joined the staff of AnnArbor.com as a food writer and community content coordinator. I spend a lot of time cooking, eating and writing, which also often feels too good to be true.
 
And now cars. I’ve been a car geek since I could walk. I caught the bug from my dad, who saved up the paychecks he earned pumping gas as a teen in western New York until he could afford a gorgeous vintage 1939 Oldsmobile. My first car was my parents’ old Dodge Spirit--an innocuous-looking car that hid a turbocharged V6 under the hood. That car took me all over the country--and fast. If I shoved a Kleenex in the tape player to stop the rattling, I could easily cruise at 120 mph, a thought that now--as a mom--strikes fear in my heart.

pageElements.text: Music and cars have long gone hand in hand. There’s something romantic about the idea of driving down the highway with the radio blasting your favorite songs. But you might have noticed that your favorite songs aren’t sounding as good as they used to, and it’s not just that your factory-installed radio can’t handle the beats. Chances are good that it’s at least partly your phone’s fault.

iPods and iPhones have revolutionized how we listen to music in our cars, for better or worse. The better: you’ve got a library of many thousands of songs at your fingertips. The worse: you’re giving up serious sound quality in exchange for all those songs. Unless you’ve customized your iTunes settings, you’ve been compressing your music as you import it to your computer, and the more you compress music files, the more sound quality you lose.
The solution: start importing your music at a lower compression rate. You’ll be able to fit fewer songs on your device, but they’ll sound so much better.

The default compression rate setting in iTunes is 128 kbps, which flattens out the music, losing important details and subtleties.  Try using a higher bitrate/lower compression setting to see if you can hear the difference.

You get the best results when using the Apple Lossless file format, but the resulting song files end up five times larger, dramatically affecting how much music fits on your player. A good compromise is to import your music at 320 kbps – you’ll get noticeably better sound without having to give up as much file space.

That’s all great, but how do you keep the volume on your iPhone from jumping or dropping from track to track? Well, it turns out that this has an even easier solution.  If you open the “settings” menu and select “music,” Apple has an option called “sound check.” Click that, and your sound levels will all be normalized.  No more jumping out of your skin when the Beethoven string quartet ends and Green Day begins.

Sure, you could invest in new car speakers, perhaps a subwoofers and sound dampeners in your car doors. But before you go to extremes, just make these two simple adjustments and see if the music doesn’t sound a whole lot better.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
One way to get to know your car better is to plan to check it over at least twice a year. It's time for that semiannual car check, and this video will take you through the steps.

Consult your owner's manual if you need to figure out where all the fluids are located under the hood, then make sure they're all at the proper levels and nothing is leaking.

Have a look at hoses that are visible and reachable.

Check your tires for correct pressure and tread depth!

Spring Cleaning for Your Car

title: 2013 Lincoln Navigator
subTitle: Big SUV has just about all the luxury you could ask for, plus all the towing and hauling capacity.
metaTitle: 2013 Lincoln Navigator - Buyer's Guide - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Lincoln Navigator SUV in the Buyer's Guide of JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Lincoln knows luxury, and if you are looking for luxury in size XXL, the Navigator might be the vehicle for you. This full-size SUV seats seven and comes in standard and extended-length forms and in rear- or all-wheel-drive versions. All are powered by a 5.4-liter V-8 that makes 310 horsepower, teamed with a smooth-shifting six-speed automatic transmission. Its towing capacity is a very capable 9,000 pounds, and it holds 128.2 cubic feet of stuff if you fold down the second row of seats. But practicality is only part of the story with the Navigator. Let’s start with the “responsibly harvested” walnut interior trim and go on upscale from there. A voice-activated touchscreen navigation system is standard, along with Sync AppLink that interacts with your smartphone, and the standard audio system is a THX II surround-sound system with fourteen (count 'em) speakers. The front seats are heated and cooled, the running boards are power deployed, and the pedals are adjustable. Safety equipment includes roll stability control with the added benefit of curve control, which maintains your hold on the Navigator when taking this big boy around curves quickly. Forward and reverse sensing systems both keep you apprised when you’re getting too close to objects. Here Lincoln gives a nod to “the full-size reality of the Navigator.”  No doubt about that! This is one large and in charge luxury vehicle for those who want to live the same way. Don’t expect favors at the gas pump, though: the Navigator tops out at 14 mpg city and 20 mpg highway for the rear-wheel-drive version, which is lowered to 13 mpg city and 18 mpg highway with all-wheel drive.
Fun-O-Meter: 5
Competitors: Cadillac Escalade, Infiniti QX56, Lexus LX570

Cool Tech: Curve control and roll stability control; power-deployable running boards; integrated blind spot mirror; Ford Sync with appLink to your smartphone; THX II surround-sound audio system with fourteen speakers
Looks: Walnut trim; optional monochrome appearance package; three new metallic paints: Kodiak Brown, Midnight Sapphire, and Ruby Red

title: 2013 Lincoln MKZ
subTitle: Mid-size Lincoln is brand-new for 2013, and it has the tech to prove it.
metaTitle: 2013 Lincoln MKZ -- Buyer's Guide -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Lincoln MKZ in JeanKnowsCars.com's Buyer's Guide.

pageElements.text: Lincoln’s mid-size MKZ sedan is all new for 2013, and Ford’s luxury brand is calling it nothing less than “the future of Lincoln.” For a car that’s not top of the lineup, the MKZ has a lot of technology and luxury to call its own, including an enormous, sweeping retractable glass roof, Active Noise Control on the inside, and real wood trim. Mechanically, there are three engine choices: a four-cylinder EcoBoost, a 3.7-liter V-6, and a hybrid version that uses the four-cylinder and gives this sedan a 41-mpg highway rating. Lincoln Drive Control is standard. As for safety features, the MKZ gets a lane-keeping suite that includes a rearview-mirror-mounted camera to read lane markers up ahead, and there’s adaptive cruise control, blind spot alert, and a collision warning system that puts on the brakes for you if you’re about to hit something. For the back-seat passengers--and you can invite them along without guilt thanks to the interior spaciousness--there are inflatable rear seatbelts on top of the eight airbags this car already has as standard; those inflatable belts are a class exclusive, Lincoln points out. All-wheel drive is an option, and active park assist is the icing on this already very well-accessorized cake.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi A4
2. Cadillac CTS
3. Lexus HS250h

Cool Tech:
1. Lincoln Drive Control, always on, ably manages ride versus handling tradeoff.
2. Lane Keeping System is a suite of driving aids to fight distraction and fatigue.
2. THX® II 700-watt audio system.

Looks:
1. Pedestal-mounted rearview mirrors.
2. Enormous retractable sunroof.

title: 2013 Lincoln MKX
subTitle: Ultramodern crossover won’t short you on comfort or amenities.
metaTitle: 2013 Lincoln MKX--Buyer's Guide -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Lincoln MKX in the Buyer's Guide of JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: For those who are looking for a practical vehicle, but not too practical, the MKX could be just right. Available in front- and all-wheel-drive versions, this luxurious crossover is priced starting just under $40,000, has a raft of up-to-date technology, and is powered by a 305-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 to get those groceries home while enjoying yourself immensely. Fuel economy is okay but not brilliant, at 19 mpg in town and 26 mpg on the highway for the front-wheel-drive version. The MKX has a wood-accented interior and an optional panoramic Vista Roof, which means you can adjust the sunroof in front while the moonroof in back remains fixed. There are dual power sunshades to go with all that opening to the sky. Technologically, there’s an expanded version of Ford Sync that includes WiFi hotspot capability and standard Operator Assist. Curve control, part of the MKX’s AdvanceTrac stability control system, helps keep you in control when taking fast curves. Optional technology includes collision warning with brake support, which uses radar to identify things you may be in danger of hitting. All that, and this is an attractive crossover, too. The aggressive dual grille may not be to everyone’s taste, but it is definitely distinctive.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi Q5
2. Cadillac SRX
3. Lexus RX

Cool Tech:
1. Curve control.
2. Sync with WiFi hotspot capability.

Looks:
1. Coming soon: twenty-two-inch polished aluminum wheels.
2. Four new exterior colors for 2013, including Ginger Ale, Ruby Red and Smoked Quartz metallic clearcoats, and Kodiak Brown metallic tri-coat.

title: 2013 Lincoln MKT
subTitle: Three big rows of comfort and luxury for the crossover crowd.
metaTitle: 2013 Lincoln MKT -- Buyer's Guide -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Lincoln MKT from JeanKnowsCars.Com.

pageElements.text: Lincoln’s 2013 MKT has the same sharp good looks as the rest of Ford’s luxury brand’s lineup. The MKT is the large crossover member of the family, and as such it has the capability to seat up to seven people in comfort. For 2013, Lincoln has added Drive Control and continuously controlled damping, which manage the tradeoff between the ability to handle this big vehicle and the comfort of the people inside. It actually adjusts the suspension twenty times per second to get that job done. The EcoBoost 3.5-liter V-6 engine has been upgraded for 365 horsepower (it was 355 hp last year). Curve control to keep you in charge of this big vehicle when going around curves, plus lane keeping technology, are welcome additions for 2013. The interior has also been refreshed, both cosmetically and with the addition of inflatable rear seatbelts. On the outside, the grille gets the new, somewhat aggressive-looking treatment similar to that of other Lincolns this year, and wheels are available in nineteen- and twenty-inch sizes. Ford’s Sync system is available in an expanded version with WiFi hotspot capability. As you might expect from such a large, luxurious crossover, Lincoln is offering it to the professional-driver market in Livery and Limousine models. But you can get your own and make it your family’s limousine.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Lexus GX460
2. Buick Enclave
3. Volvo XC90

Cool Tech:
1. Curve control.
2. Continuously controlled damping improves ride and handling.
3. Expanded Ford Sync with WiFi hotspot capability.
4. Inflatable rear seatbelts.

Looks:
1. New interior styling.

title: Why Be Like Me and Work on Your First Car?
subTitle: You'll be inspired by this
promoTitle: Why Be Like Me and Work on Your First Car?
promoTeaserSmall: Your first car doesn't exist to get you ripped off by mechanics, but as an opportunity to connect.
promoTeaser: Your first car doesn't exist to get you ripped off by mechanics, but as an opportunity to connect.
keywords: Why Be Like Me and Work on Your First Car?
metaTitle: Why Be Like Me and Work on Your First Car? -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Why Be Like Me and Work on Your First Car?
metaDescription: Why Be Like Me and Work on Your First Car? Learn about how one writer got involved in fixing up old cars at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I've always had cars on the brain. I turned my first wrench when I was about four, growing up among my dad's collection of weird old British and American classics. In adolescence, I was rifling through back issues of Hot Rod and Car Craft, clipping out photos and articles on fire-breathing hot rods. And after adopting my mom's old Ford Escort, I started getting part-time jobs in garages, which sustained me all the way through college and grad school. I completed the restoration of my first car on student loans, and I currently own a total of four vintage vehicles, all of which I work on. Even after earning two academic degrees and toiling most of the way through a third, my heart remained in the garage, and just as my doctoral funding ran out, I got a break on a dream job that would allow me to combine my two major life passions: writing and cars. I've been writing about cars, covering motorsports and car shows, and having a ton of hell-raising adventures as an editor at CarDomain.com since 2007.

pageElements.text: When I was sixteen, I changed the oil in my hand-me-down '82 Ford Escort. I was broke, it needed to get done, and no one had told me I couldn't.

In that deluge of black sludge, and the ensuing ultimately triumphant wrestling match I had with the filter, something began to take hold. I'd been disdainful of that Escort, my betrothed first car, my mom's long-haul commuter that had sat for many months after being taken off the road because of a bad wheel bearing. The car was ten years old, slow and ugly and uncool, and I was an ingrate. As soon as I got my license, the car was mine for the taking, I was always told, if I could figure out how to fix it.
Fix it? Resentfully, when the time came, I had it towed to the family mechanic, who fixed it for me.

But the night when I changed the oil marked the beginning of a shift. I went to bed dirty and happy. Shortly thereafter, I picked up a Ford Escort shop manual. I swapped out brake pads. I started messing around with different kinds of spark plugs and learned to tinker on the temperamental old carb. I took that car on its first road trip along the Oregon coast, where I live, and later drove it from Vancouver to Las Vegas and back. Then I  got a part-time job at a local garage and signed up for a correspondence program in "auto mechanics" from a fake mail-order college, which I completed concurrently with actual college. And when I got accepted to grad school in New York, that Escort took me across the country and into the rest of my life.

So what would I advise you to do?

Getting an older vehicle that's a bit marginal is a great place to start, especially when you're a girl. Especially in a culture that often subtly undermines girls' efficacy and self-sufficiency. Because an old car teaches you self-sufficiency. And humility. And troubleshooting. And how to prevail over your doubters. And how to recognize which problems are beyond your ability.

Your first car doesn't exist to get you ripped off by predatory mechanics, as everybody fears it will, but as an opportunity to connect and collaborate with trusted others. Even with the most lightly used tool set, you'll develop the skills and the patterns of thought necessary to overcome challenges that haven’t even occurred to you yet.  And even as your car teaches you self-sufficiency, it also teaches you symbiosis. You keep this fragile old creature running happily, and in return it gets you to school and work each day, and it's all miraculously rewarding.

Though it seems impossible, my Escort now wears collector-vehicle plates and I’ve owned it for nearly twenty years. I've swapped in a bigger engine and a five-speed transmission and commissioned extensive structural surgery and a tri-stage custom paint job. I wouldn't necessarily recommend getting in as deep as I did: I now own three other cars besides the Escort, all of which I work on, and I have garage needs that permanently disqualify me from ever being able to live in LA or New York City.

I also concede that it's very likely possible to lead a richly fulfilling life without ever once turning a wrench on your own car: you can always sign up for a burly car payment on something brand-new with a service plan, and thus gain freedom from ever having to think about your car. But what you're paying for is the happy disconnect known as “peace of mind,” which isn’t the same as wisdom or patience or skill. These things can be given to you by a humbler car with a much lower price. If you're up for a bit of adventure, don't buy something that's so fancy that you're locked out of even changing the oil on it; try your hand at a good used car instead. You don't need to be able to fix everything. Initially, you don't even need to know how to hold a wrench. Trust yourself: what you get out of it might end up being worth the journey.
